It took me a while to find my footing with Baldur’s Gate 3. At first, I felt like I was watching someone else’s story—so many systems, so much lore, and a world that didn’t seem to need me. I kept bouncing off it, wondering if maybe it just wasn’t for me. Then I finished Clair Obscur. And something shifted. The tone, the ambiguity, the way it let light and shadow coexist without forcing resolution… it made me realize this wasn’t just a game about choices. It was a game about consequences. About emotional weight. About living with what you’ve done, even when you’re not sure why you did it. Now, I get it. Baldur’s Gate 3 isn’t trying to win you over in the first hour. It’s asking you to stay. To wrestle with it. To let it unfold. And when it does, it’s unforgettable. If you’re someone who needs time to settle into a world—who values emotional texture over instant gratification—give it that time. It’s worth it.

I'm leaving a negative review for one very simple reason.... BLOAT Do you REALLY think that it is acceptable for a game to require 150GB install space? Is that what you want out of games going forward? Unoptimized messes? Some are going to say "but the game is so BIG". But I don't see how this game is any more impressive than Divinity Original Sin 2 is from a gameplay perspective. Sure, the graphical fidelity is increased and we got cinematic dialogue.... In a CRPG... I'm sorry, those things matter to a CRPG? No, they do not. Fact of the matter is. BG3, even though it is pretty good, is not that much of a massive jump from D:OS2 that it warrants a +130% install size. CRPG's are not supposed to be AAA games. This is bloat. Simple as. There is no other arguing about it. If you think that this is important for a CRPG then you don't like CRPG's in general. You like AAA slop. And if it isn't cinematic then you wouldn't touch it. Game's fine otherwise, gameplay mechanics of D:OS2 is better than BG3. BG3's cinematics makes dialogue more immersive than D:OS2. But is this what I want out of a CRPG? Absolutely not. And do I want bloatware out of ANY game? No. Bloatware is just a sign of developer incompetence to me. I doubt we'll get another good CRPG out of Larian. Next game will probably be 200GB and you lot will probably rationalize why that's fine because we can see the pores on the labia for the sex scenes. :rolleyes:

The Best Game Ever Made In my opinion, and from the perspective of an avid gamer, this is the best game ever made. The only thing I dislike is that I fear a game of this quality may never be made again. Whether you're unfamiliar with Dungeons and Dragons, either its world or gameplay, or whether you're an avid fantasy fan, this game is for you. The turn-based roleplay-focused gameplay means even the most casual gamer can enjoy this game, despite its amazing depth. Every element of the world, from the barrels to the monsters, is hand-picked and carefully designed for its place. Enemies are put in positions that allow for unique battle approaches, areas are set up to award exploration and out-of-the-box thinking, and stories are beautifully interwoven with gameplay to make you feel like you are a part of the world. Although its turn-based gameplay may be off-putting to those who prefer more action-packed experiences, I urge those who are wary to take a chance, as Baldur's Gate 3 is amazing whether you enjoy turn-based combat or not. The biggest issues you may face are likely going to be due to inherent shortcomings of the Dungeons and Dragons format, which although is not the game's fault, can be a detractor. In specific, the RNG-based attacks and spells can be annoying, and the disparity between caster and martial classes is frustrating. The characters are, perhaps, the best part of Baldur's Gate 3 and what really ties everything together. Every NPC in the game, from your party companions to random townsfolk, are unique and exciting, and make you want to continue playing to further your interactions with them. I feel that even the most disconnected players will become enthralled with the characters and their story. Even after competing the game once, I feel that there is a lot of potential for further playthroughs; and this is coming from someone who abhors doing things all over again. You could do the classic evil/good playthrough, venture out with a different set of companions, experience what it's like to be as different classes with unique builds, or even just go through and try things you may have missed or approach encounters in different ways. All in all, Baldur's Gate 3 is a masterpiece of a game and one I believe will go down in history as being a monument to what makes video games great in the future.

Especially before and after every dialogue if character progression matters to you. I feel like a lot of emphasis is put on characters who are extremely annoying to me, Shadowheart, is absolutely my very least favorite. I also want to tell the devs they took the freedom out of evil play with happy endings away from us as players. Every evil playthrough will have a terrible ending. some say it's just right for an evil playthrough to have a bad ending, but for players who want to be evil, why do the devs have to focus on such disney-esque endings and for villains, we get nothing? Otherwise a stellar game. Needs a better map system because I am constantly getting lost and having to watch Ytube for puzzle solving. I get it, D&D has puzzles but that is why D&D online failed. I finally finished the game so this review has been a long time coming. I love this game. Everything about this game is well thought out and the years it put in towards making it have paid off in such a wonderful experience. I got the game shortly after it was released and to see it improve with the updates it has had just tells me how much Larian Studios cares about their work. It's no secret that this game can be awesome when modded, but even without mods it's still an amazing play. The voice acting of the characters is amazing, the stories themselves are amazing, even the play style is amazing. This is also a wonderful introduction to DND if you or a friend are having a hard time figuring out the mechanics. I've played DND for a long time and this game helped me visualize things as a player. There are lots of secret dialogue and choices you can make based upon your race and class and I'm really happy they took the time and effort to do that. Finishing the game finally made me burst into tears, it was so rewarding and so bittersweet to see that end credit screen. This is a game that is so much fun to be replayed as a different race and class every time. This is my favorite game by far and despite it's cost, it is so worth the money.

I have wanted this game for monthhhhhsss, and I thought I couldn't get it on my (relatively) old MacBook Air, but I finally got it and I am so happy. It is everything I hoped it would be- with ONE exception: the camera controls for the MacBook mean that you can't toggle the "height (angle? pitch axis?)" of the camera. It's really hard to look into spaces and see where you are going because of this. I understand there is a mod for computers with Windows, but it's frustrating this isn't built in as standard for the game, and also isn't available for MacBooks (although, yes I know, MacBook Air isn't really built for these kinds of games). It would also be useful to have an initial trial option for different classes during character creation, so that you can try out the combat styles for different classes and see if you like it before committing to starting a game. In addition, it would be helpful to have a tutorial section on exactly how combat and building a character works in a slow, very broken-down, idiot-proof way. You can absolutely still enjoy the game and play well without this kind of tutorial but I found when I watched some YouTube videos that did do the job of breaking down how to understand what each spell or attack actually achieves I enjoyed the game a lot more because I wasn't making "blind" decisions with the limited information I had available from just trial and error of playing. This difference became more clear when I was helping someone else on their first time playing because each time I would point something out or explain something they would go "oh well that's not very intuitive, is it?". I do believe in trial and error making things more fun in a game, and also that certain aspects of optimising the game experience should involve further reading and engaging in classic game nerd discussions (e.g., stats building, spell/weapon comparisons, lore, hacks, easter eggs, etc.), but it is frustrating that further reading should be needed from the outset of playing as a beginner in order to understand what you're doing at a basic enough level to not feel like you're blindly wandering around. I know that seems like a hefty set of complaints, but I really do want to emphasise that this game is fun! I haven't played any computer games in almost 10 years, and was always more of an MMORPG kind of person, and this game is everything I want from a fantasy RPG. I love the environment, it is beautiful; I love all the characters' personalities; I love the gameplay, and I love the flexibility.

Baldur’s Gate 3 is a nice game, but I think I prefer Divinity: Original Sin 2 in terms of character design, worldbuilding, and especially combat. Playing BG3 made me realize that I really dislike D&D's approach to magic, it feels restrictive and disjointed. The spell slot system discourages me from using the big, flashy spells I enjoy, and the magic schools feel like arbitrary categories rather than cohesive playstyles. Unlike DOS2, where elemental magic offers a clear identity and fun synergies, D&D's spell list feels like a grab bag of effects with little overarching logic. Even at high levels, magic rarely delivers a true power fantasy unless you use a handful of standout spells, and too many cool abilities are situational or impractical. While I appreciate BG3's strong character interactions, its combat system ultimately left me frustrated rather than empowered.

Baldur’s Gate 3 – A Masterclass in Modern RPGs Baldur’s Gate 3 is one of those rare games that truly delivers on the promise of giving players freedom and immersion in a living, breathing world — and it does so with style. One of the first things that hits you is just how excellent the voice acting and direction are. Every major and minor character feels authentic, their performances bringing out genuine emotion and nuance. You’re not just hearing lines — you’re feeling what the characters want you to feel, whether that’s tension, heartbreak, camaraderie, or pure dread. It adds an incredible layer of immersion that few RPGs manage to hit consistently. Another huge plus is how approachable this game is for newcomers. If this is your first foray into the Baldur’s Gate series (or even Dungeons & Dragons), don’t worry — this is a completely standalone story set in the universe of other standalone stories. There’s no required homework here. Veterans will catch references and Easter eggs, but new players can dive in and enjoy a complete experience on its own merits. Combat is a highlight in its own right. The turn-based system is incredibly fun, rewarding both tactical thinking and creative problem-solving. On higher difficulties, it provides an exceptional challenge for those wanting to test their mettle — you will need to think several moves ahead. On the flip side, if you just want to feel like an unstoppable force, playing on lower difficulties is very forgiving. In fact, on lower settings, it’s not uncommon to see enemies and even bosses get reduced to one-tap territory — so the game really lets you choose your power fantasy level. Speaking of which, the custom difficulty options are fantastic. The ability to tailor your experience down to the smallest details — like how the bartering and trade system functions — is one of those quality-of-life features that every RPG should take note of. You can shape the game around exactly how you want to play, and that level of flexibility is a huge win. A personal favorite touch: the mod manager built into the game. Huge shout-out to the devs for making it so smooth — no digging through folders or downloading from third-party sites. You can grab what you want directly through the game, which lowers the barrier to entry and encourages players to experiment and customize. More games should follow this example. Finally, character customization and class progression are very solid. Whether you want to min-max or roleplay a quirky build, the tools are here, and they feel meaningful. As your character grows, choices matter — both mechanically and narratively — which only deepens your investment in your party and their journey. Final Verdict: Baldur’s Gate 3 is a modern RPG done right: immersive, flexible, approachable, and packed with heart. Whether you’re a newcomer or a veteran, a story-driven player or a tactical combat fiend, this game delivers. It’s not just a great Baldur’s Gate game — it’s one of the best RPGs of its generation. Rating: 9.5/10

ENGLISH Baldur’s Gate 3 isn’t just a good RPG — it’s an absolute masterclass. The writing is incredibly rich, every choice truly matters, and the game constantly manages to surprise you, even after dozens of hours. The gameplay perfectly blends the depth of Dungeons & Dragons with the accessibility of a modern video game. Turn-based combat is demanding but deeply rewarding, and every situation can be approached in countless ways: diplomacy, stealth, or just sending in the big barbarian to smash through the door. Each companion has a strong, memorable personality, to the point where you genuinely grow attached to them (or sincerely hate them). And the presentation… cinematic, movie-level quality, while still giving you complete freedom. FRENCH Baldur’s Gate 3 n’est pas juste un bon RPG : c’est une masterclass absolue. L’écriture est d’une richesse incroyable, chaque choix compte vraiment, et le jeu arrive à surprendre constamment, même après des dizaines d’heures. Le gameplay mélange à la perfection la profondeur de Donjons & Dragons et l’accessibilité d’un jeu vidéo moderne. Les combats au tour par tour sont exigeants mais gratifiants, et chaque situation peut être résolue de mille façons : diplomatie, infiltration, ou gros barbare qui traverse la porte. Chaque compagnon a une personnalité marquante, au point que tu t’attaches (ou détestes) sincèrement chacun d’eux. Et la mise en scène… digne d’un film, mais avec ta liberté totale derrière.

Man, this is one of those time when I wish steam had a middleground option rather than just recomend or don't. It's... ok. Honestly the more I get back to it and try to play it, the more I start to believe the people that say this only blew up because of the high production values, which while that can be a nice bonus, is on the bottom of the list for things I care about in a good game. The story is... fine. It's fairly generic DnD, and theres not enough choice variation outside of a few quest to make it interesting to me. The mechanics and system are based off a far too simplified version of DnD to the point where it's just kind of boring. Divinity Original Sin 2 had more build diversity and mechanics than this game. Honestly every time I play this I kind of just wish I was playing that instead. The setting is far more unique and interesting too. Weird skinny elves that absorb memories through eating other living beings? I'll take that any day over generic, pretty high elf and drow tropes. The writing is ok, for the most part, but it just feels servicable. The voice acting and constant cutscenes just detract from the experience for me. Everyone talks so SLOW compared to my reading speed, and the facial animations are crazy awkward to the point of breaking immersion. I do not get the praise on that aspect, the flaws in character animations show up as early as the prologue. The characters aren't even all that interesting compared to other crpgs. If anything, I find them fairly basic and boring for the most part. Even the ones I find ok are just that, ok. Artorius is probably the best of the bunch if I had to pick someone. I try to give the game a shot but I get bored and burn out by mid game. Every time I play this I just wish I was playing an Owlcat rpg or something. I could stay engrossed in Warhammer Roguetrader through an entire playthrough for 270ish hours and not get bored once, despite it being my first 40k game, but I struggle to keep intrest in Balders Gate 3 long enough to even get halfway through. I have to give props to the devs for all the updates they've put into the game sense launch, credit where it's due and all. But man, I just do not get the appeal to this game. I'm just going to have to accept that I'm the odd one out on this title.

Baldur's Gate 3 is the CRPG masterpiece we've all been waiting for-a sprawling D&D epic that reinvents the genre with a fresh, player-driven story packed with moral ambiguity, hilarious companions, and gut-wrenching choices that ripple across 100+ hours of play. The narrative takes the classic Baldur's Gate formula and infuses it with cerebral horror: you're infected with a mind flayer tadpole, racing to cure it while navigating alliances with devils, gods, and goblins. It's bold, reactive, and never predictable. Animation is next-level-fluid combat, expressive faces during cutscenes, and those tiny idle animations that make the world feel alive. Voice acting is phenomenal: every line, from Astarion's silky sarcasm to Shadowheart's quiet intensity, is delivered by pros who elevate the script to Shakespearean heights. Gameplay blends deep tactics, exploration, and romance into pure addiction. It's dense, but the freedom is intoxicating. 9.5/10-Larian redefined RPGs. Play it now.

Hands down an amazing and lovely game. The game is really pretty with breathtaking graphics and great world details, like birdsi n the background playing to catch seeds. The amount of stuff they prepared for the dialogues is amazing. Every possible situation - there's a line there for it. The locations are cool which is strengthened by the fact you can sneak in almost everywhere due to multiple paths being available to you. Most battles are well-designed and balanced allowing challenge where needed and leniency where sought. The satisfaction of levelling up and building the character is extremely high and can't be understated - I loved building my character up. Insanely epic Raphael fight as well as the last fight. The soundtracks were thorugh the roof! The ending is incredible and satisfying and the romancing in the game is an amazing feature. That being said, there were a couple of negative aspects to the game which I remember. Critical failures have to go - they are a bane of all the builds. Some things just aren't left to luck, as in you can't suddenly sound less imposing due to... luck? Bugs have not been properly addressed, like the "no action in combat bug" which I only had once but it was really annoying. Jaheira in the dialogue within the inn knows you have an artifact even if you keep it in secret from her earlier at the gates. You can't tell Isobel about killing the mage in Act 3, even if you have done so with Aylin - these dialogue mistakes broke immersion and honestly - made some part of gameplay leading thereto quite less meaningful. Can't save in Oubliette (this blocks the ability to save game forever, error 804) - another bug which almost ended my playthrough and I know for a fact many people did away with the game because of it. Zrell fight - auto-crits on Absolute paladins? Seriously? I replayed the fight four times and they persisted. Exxvikyap just ends the dialogue if you tell her the monk dialogue option - this is just funny. You can't activate Call Lightning while in Wild Shape - what the heck? Why would they do this thing to the Druids? It's an important part of the kit, always has been. Some textures are extremely low-quality in several shots, notably outside of the dialogues. (Spoiler!!!!) The game makes you believe stuff which isn't true - like "you are on a timer" and "the world will end tomorrow" basically. Which makes you spend less time long-resting, leading to less dialogues and similar encounters. Too many weird ♥♥♥♥ in quests require you to google stuff - like Arabella disappearing and bugging out if you did not speak to her at one particular point no one tells you about. Dream Visitor can't be killed and Astral Prism can't be given out which makes the story incredibly linear and lame at first. The Chosen just explain their plot out loud... lacking any means of perception to notice us crouching behind some crap and riding a whole elevator to get there. These are just plotholes everybody chose to ignore when designing the game. Every save weighs a ton which is not a problem until you log out of a gaming session and have to upload them via steam for 10-15 minutes, which is annoying. But not nearly as annoying as Shroud Self + Sanctuary cultists - not strong or difficult to deal with, just irritating Tolna Tome-Monger can target you with Disintegrate through the roof and walls, but god forbid you try to target comeone through a barrel. Puzzles like in Sorcerous Vault are the type of "we never state the key, so just mash the buttons" which is not fun The cutscene after telling the "Avenge the Drowned" questgiver you killed the beastmaster is bugged - no lines appear. The pathfinding in the game is ludicrous. A ton of times my character would be like "Oh yeah, let me autofind the path to this secret location, but yeah, I can't jump across the hall, I'll get stuck in the chandelier". Wyll does not acknowledge his father is saved until you actually talk to him The enemy has Motivators. What are we going to do once we got rid of some of them, secured the place and brought our families to safety? Keep wearing the collars and die like slaves, that's right. The amount of xp you get and don't need is staggering. Why not just make two more levels, up to 14? This last thing made me scratch my head so many times. This much content in Act 3 for... these few levels? Ridiculous. But overall - a lovely game which I hope will get more polished in the future. This gave me so many good memories and helped spend time in a really fun way.

So much has been said about this game already, so I'll try to make this brief. I really, really DISLIKE Dungeons & Dragons. To me it's campy, uninspired, and uninteresting. A kind of generic fantasy setting full of worn-out tropes and inspirations that are so low-bar and in-your-face, it sometimes beggars belief. But Baldur's Gate 3 is fantastic. I'm 62 hours in and I can't get enough. The storytelling is great. The dialogues are mostly excellent. The voice acting is amazing. The gameplay is terrific. I turn off the music in most modern games because usually it's just so bad (and I'm a melomaniac), but the music in this game is simply beautiful. I constantly find myself shaking my head in amazement at how good some of those tracks are. So, yeah. All those glowing reviews aren't lying. This one is really that good. EDIT#1: The writing takes a nosedive in Act 3; both story-wise, and in dialogues. I find myself skipping some of the talking. The shortcomings of the setting (D&D itself) are also becoming exacerbated. EDIT#2: The final stages, the climax, the ending, and the epilogue were as generic, boring, lazy and underwhelming as any run-of-the-mill fantasy RPG from the last 20 years. Wholly unworthy of the excellent first two acts. What an absolute and utter disappointment. Perhaps it is a testament to the banality of Dungeons & Dragons itself — whatever one tries to do to elevate the source material into something better, its triviality always ends up being a glass ceiling no medium can ever hope to transcend. I'm positive this wouldn't have been the case if pen-and-paper Warhammer were to receive the Larian treatment. Of course one can only dream...

I have played the game for over 100 hours and am currently in ACT 2. Here are my thoughts: Combat is very slow and not exciting. Yeah, it's from D&D, but it didn't have to be in my opinion. Exploration is tedious and slow. Mods can help with that. You don't feel like you are the character you made. Character creation is very limited, it's just presets. Mods can help with adding more, but i.g. it's pretty lame. Every character is voice, but the one that you play. In a story driven game, that is minus point. SWTOR did it and it's an MMO. The Story so far has been pretty good. Many of the main characters start out being insufferable, especially Astarion, but they all seem to have a pretty well-written character and story. The overall story and how the side missions merge into the main story is well done. You won't really find yourself going away to do all the side missions and then continue on the main story, but rather most of the side missions are on the way of the main mission. Lastly, the puzzles are horrendous, the worst I have ever seen. Mostly you have to find some other detail in some book you might or might not have picket up somewhere or there's a hint anywhere on the room, that you might not see. Some of them are luckily bypassable by automatically succeeding a perception check to reveal a button on the wall, that just skips the whole thing, but it doesn't really make the puzzle any better. When there isn't such an option it can get very frustrating: In the Gauntlet there is this labyrinth puzzle, where you just die, when you misstep. Which is very costly in this game. Even with all the hints in the room, completing it, is guess work, and the cost of failure. Well realistly it's a reload, which makes this whole experience not rewarding. You can't skip it with dimension door either, cause everything is shrouded in darkness, so your character can't see it. Tldr: The story and characters are amaizing. The gameplay is pretty bad however, which makes for a grueling experience to get through the story.

What can I say? I want to like it. I really do. There are parts of it I do actually enjoy. But overall, this is very much not the game for me. Act 1 had me hooked. Act 2 had me slightly annoyed. Act 3 was bad enough I had to mod it to finish it. The camera is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ nightmare, the combat feels like a slog through molasses, the RNG definetly favors the enemies. The fact I had to do almost two hours of prep work and research to make it through one large combat encounter, on Explorer mode, broke me. I played D&D 5e for awhile before I started BG3, and while I do enjoy the world building and the roleplaying aspects for the most part, the combat is honestly the worst part of this game. Theres literally no justifiable reason my entire beefed up squad with meta gear and stats should struggle with a group of lizard people, on the games easiest difficulty. The only workaround Ive found that takes the combat from nearly an hour per conflict (obviously dependant on size of enemy group) is to cheese the ♥♥♥♥ out of items and set up a trap guantlet before starting the combat. Which, if I was playing on hard or above, I could respect. But I wasnt. Overall, BG3 had great potential for being one of the better games Ive played, but quality of life and combat/balancing issues abound doesnt make me want to play this game ever again. Finishing it felt like a chore and frankly thats just not fun.

Very good game, it does actually live up to the hype for the most part. Played it several times including a completed honour mode run, however the game does have some very glaring flaws. Pros: - Story is brilliant, the main story is the weakest part, the game shines in the side characters and companions and everything they bring. - Combat is very good if you like turn based systems, character customisation and gear hunting. This game really rewards creativity and exploration, there is build defining gear everywhere. Be aware that the games combat and systems very quickly break down when you start finding these items - even in the hardest difficulty you can fast approach optimisation of one-round murdering major bosses, so depending on what you want in a game then you may consider this a balancing issue. In general - glass cannon is the way to play this game. - I didn't expect this game to be as funny as it is, a lot of credit needs to go to the writing department and the voice acting. These are the things that truly, truly carry this game. Cons: - The UI in this game is very weak around anything to do with inventory, so many restrictions and things that should be able to happen seemingly not working. You can only stack items in the store menu if you're using the character you're in the store for, despite the fact it loads all inventories. Organisation is also a complete mess - however is solved by mods for containers and organisation. Items also have no item description flags without mods, there is seemingly hundreds of items in this game and it is hard to tell which of them are useful or not, especially if they are miscalanious, simple coloured backgrounds or borders would of sufficed. I believe in the ethos that if I have to google what a misc item is for then the game has failed in it's delivery of information. There is a half way point between what I would want and what the game gives me that would of been a lot better than what we got. - Bugs: This is honestly the big one for me. For a game this large and looked after, I am very dissapointed in how many bugs are in this game. In my Honour mode runs I was tasked with dealing with the consequences of game-changing and run altering unexpected bugs, this shouldn't be a feature. It can be from falling through the floor and dying. NPC's not behaving as you'd expect of them, or things disappearing. Every time I encountered something I thought was a bug a quick google confirmed to me that I wasn't stupid, I didn't make a narrative mistake, and it was bugged for the sake of being bugged. - The camera. Honestly, I find that it sucks. It's especially bad in one of the final dungeons of act 2 running and jumping down a slope. It is aggregiously bad when you have fights inside buildings. I hope the devs take a lesson from XCOM for this and introduce a "level-up" and "level-down" button for when you are dealing with heights, I think it desperately needs it. - For a game of this scope and size the character customisation is frankly quite bad, I expected a lot better customisation options than the ones we got, mods thankfully fix this. - No achievements when you use mods. I get it, some of them are stupid, feels like some more nuance could of been taken with this in a way to flag aestetic/UI mods to not disable achievements. Did my second playthrough with UI and Inventory mods and it disabled my achievements. I do feel a bit robbed because these were the things I had my major gripes with in the game and I would of liked to get them without having to struggle through dealing with the vanilla inventory system. Personal gripe: I think the EXP balancing in this game is very unrewarding. Playing "thin" in this game power levels you to level cap with absolute ease and nothing ever level or gear checked me that I ran into. I'm of the opinion that in games like this that exploration and playing wide should be a reward for this. There is a level 20 cap mod that seems popular and I completely see why. This game is screaming to me for a better balanced level curve in it. Found myself on my second playthrough being at the level cap for more than half of the runs duration.

This game is what every modern RPG has to take notes from. The open ended game progression reminds me a lot of one of my favourite games, Fallout: New Vegas; you can choose what you want to do within each act outside of the main story and it will effect the rest of the game. Choices you make in Act 1 will change the NPCs in Acts 2 and 3 drastically, sometimes locking you out of content (which isn't bad for replay ability in an RPG). The setting and characters are interesting and for any fan of Dungeons and Dragons: Fifth Edition you'll enjoy a canonical experience of the franchise. If you're a real DnD nerd you'll recognise a lot of the name drop characters, and even meet a couple of them. The gameplay is really sold, with a lot of build choices within the Player's Handbook of 5e. Each with their own subclasses and the ability to bridge into multiple classes through multi-classing. You can create a custom "Tav" character just like you would create your own player character in 5e; all the options are there. I have nothing bad to say about this game. If you enjoy top down turn based RPG games, then this is the gold standard. The only disappointment is the controversy between the developer studio and publisher which lead them to indefinitely halt any DLC or expansions. So we can't expect any large content drops in the future, the base game is what it is; although it is already a fully fleshed out, enjoyable, large game you can pump hundreds of hours into. The developers plan to drop one new subclass for each of the classes as a Christmas-like gift to the players in January 2025, otherwise it's back to only bug fixes in patches.

4/10 to balance out the hype. Just like the last big gaming releases backed by social media marketing, the release of Baldur's Gate 3 has again pointed to the roots of marketing hypes and public relations: Propaganda. People become devotees up in arms against anyone who stands in the way of its Gloriousness, its Holyness, its Singularity. "GOTY, GOTY, GOTY !!!", consumed and forgotten one after the other. It's sad to see how the name of Baldur's Gate is used for an entirely different game that is also a part of all this frenetic and agitated hollowness that is shaping the current gaming industry as well as groupthink mentality. In this context, the actual game and its content have become pretty much irrelevant. BG3 is a professional industry-product. But it has almost nothing in common with the original 2 games. So what's the difference between BG 3 and the original two games which stayed in the memories of a whole generation of gamers? - BG 1+2: A personal journey with mysterious locations, epic tales, and legendary treasures to uncover. You start as a nobody that slowly gets involved in grander schemes while growing in power until your party fights the very gods that tried to exploit you. Pacing is great. - BG 3: A sequence of beautiful but arbitrary set pieces with random junk loot scattered around. The story starts with a bombastic climax as your lvl 1 party is already breaking out **** flying prison made out of tentacles. - BG 1+2: At its time an innovative and very fun combat system, "real time with pause", that translated the D&D rules to the computer medium and kept the narrative flowing while still providing a lot of tactical maneuverability because you could pause the action at any time. - BG 3: Common and generally slow turn-based system adapted from Divinity Original Sin where archdemons wait in line like orderly citizens. - BG 1+2: Charming and endearing characters with a wide range of personalities. Jon Irenicus as an iconic villain. - BG 3: In essence and in contrast to the supposed "uniqueness", the companions of BG3 act very trendy. The style is hip, the substance is square. A nod to mainstream fiction which is full of edgy antiheroes. - BG 1 + 2: Witty and nuanced high fantasy, reflections on the human condition and the thirst for power. - BG 3: Complete checklist of aggravatingly shallow identity politics, that fails to reflect that fiction can be more than just superficial representation without becoming reactionary. A disservice to truely progressive politics because of the heavy-handed moralizing involved. - BG 1+2: A gift by crazily talented people that wanted to share their passion. - BG 3: A fancy and stylized product based on a famous brand, made by industry experts. - BG 1+2: Ran on an average computer, just as Divinity Original Sin 2 which provided the engine for BG3. - BG3: Time to upgrade! Overpriced graphic cards have long enough been waiting for such an opportunity. After all these years, Baldur's Gate 3 doesn't change direction by building on its predecessors strengths, it rather escalates a sad trend by trying to assimilate the identity and brand of good old games while omitting most of the original's defining content.

The definition of innovative game design. BG3 perfectly incorporates and finds a balance between story where player's choices would slowly affect its surrounding, and gameplay where the class system adds tremendously deep gameplay and build options; and still manages to do an outstanding job on both, everything about this game is fascinating. What truly made me drop my jaws the most was the "core" mechanics of the game, and that is, choice. Nearly everything around you is interactive with your moves, spells or attacks. In addition, the dialogue and outcomes would also change according to the player's speech and choice of dialogue options, allowing the player to truly "represent" themselves as their in game characters. Where we truly follow our own nature to make decisions, make allies and enemies, build relations according to our own preferences, leaving the player with nearly infinitely many outcomes possible in the story. Probably one of my favorite games EVER, would want to get a surgery to remove my memory in order to experience this masterpiece again, 100/10 game y'all should give it a try.

Baldur’s Gate 3: A Masterpiece of RPGs (Astarion Is the Best Part) Baldur’s Gate 3 is everything I’ve ever wanted from an RPG and more. The game beautifully blends deep storytelling, complex characters, and tactical combat with the rich lore of the Dungeons & Dragons universe. Every decision you make has weight, and the freedom to shape your character and the world around you is truly remarkable. The environments are beautifully detailed, and the story keeps you on the edge of your seat with constant twists and turns. But let’s talk about Astarion. From his wit to his backstory, he’s easily one of the most captivating companions in the game. His charm, depth, and personality will have you hooked from the moment he joins your party. Would I Recommend It? Yes, without a doubt. Baldur’s Gate 3 is an incredible RPG that offers hours of content, meaningful decisions, and a truly engaging narrative. If you’re a fan of the genre, it’s a must-play. And if you’re looking for a character to fall in love with (metaphorically, of course), Astarion is a fantastic companion. His wit, charm, and complex story make him a highlight of the game. ⭐ 10/10 – A stunning RPG with memorable characters, and Astarion? He’s the cherry on top.

This is the first CRPG I've played where I had the impression that the game might notify law enforcement of choices made in game. There is something unsettling about it. There is very obviously a "correct" way to play the game, and an "incorrect" way. I did not care for the 120GB download. That assessment may be at least a partial reflection of the fact BG3 is significantly different from BG1 and 2, grognard discomfort with change, etc. But while there seems to be lots of "choices and consequences" I have the distinct impression there isn't actually much flexibility. In fairness, the 'chosen one' story kind of precludes that, but that kind of story always irks me. And it's blasted into the user's face immediately! BG1 had a much better approach - didn't really get a sense of the player character's role in the plot until later in the game (Of course, Arcanum has the best version of the 'chosen one' story imo). Also, very PO'd that there was no players' guide or equivalent in game. Owlcat did this well in their Pathfinder games, so there was no excuse for BG3 to exclude that information on character advancement, spells, etc. Even the OG BG1 and 2 let you look up those details. Going from 6 to 4 characters is a little lame but not a dealbreaker; however I do not care for the lack of alignment associated with characters. Perhaps that's how D&D plays now but it's stupid and lazy. Don't care for the moral relativism implied and it obviously causes problems with not-even-remotely-relativistic classes like paladins - yes, the paladin oath system is stupid. Lack of alignment obviously neuters squabbles between clerics and the pantheon too. Again, maybe thats a D&D thing now and not the studio's interpretation, in which case nu-D&D or whatever . BG3 is very strong in presentation though - the game runs smoothly, looks good (mostly), and to be honest it would probably be a great engine for modders to build their own campaigns on, but this ain't Neverwinter either. Pity. One area where it's presentation fails is the music and soundtrack. There is nothing dynamic about anything I've heard thus far, which is unfortunate as both BG1 and 2 had some very memorable themes. I haven't finished the game but also may or may not (at present, wandering around Moonrise Towers) - it just feels too locked up to me. I'll give a specific example here, and if i can actually do what I am attempting to do I'll edit this review accordingly to eat crow. I am attempting to play off the various players introduced around the Moonrise Towers off against each other, like a fantasy Yojimbo. I suspect I will be forced to "choose a side" regardless, at which point I may just give up on BG3. We'll see. (I was already quite annoyed by the game's direction rubbing my nose in my resolution of the first set piece. Thanks, I know what the player character decided to do, No, actually they were all useless to my purpose, but .) Disappointed grognard noises.

A generational banger. I was pretty skeptical at first since turn-based games never really grabbed me. The only one that ever pulled me in before this was Wakfu, which I actually really enjoyed for a while. But Baldur’s Gate 3? It hit different. Once it got its hooks in, it never let go. The combat is super fun once you get into it, and the freedom you have is just wild. You can go anywhere, do anything, and the game actually reacts to it. The story is packed with memorable moments and epic boss fights, made even better by the amazing music. The origin characters are done so well. You grow close to them, and you can totally betray them if you want. That kind of freedom is rare. The world feels alive, like you're really paving your own path instead of just following a set story. It actually feels like a proper Dungeons and Dragons campaign, rules and all. And as good as it is solo, it gets even better when played with friends. The chaos, the laughs, the unexpected decisions with your party add a whole new layer to the experience. But don’t worry. If turn-based stuff isn’t your thing, just play it on easy and enjoy the ride. Learn the basics, and you’ll be surprised how natural it starts to feel. The characters, the dialogue, the music... it’s all superbly done. One of the best games I’ve played in years.

Saving the World… After I Finish My 70 Naps Baldur's Gate 3 isn't merely a great role-playing game; it is a structural anomaly. It is, in effect, a proof-of-concept that demonstrates what happens when a major budget is deployed not in pursuit of the live-service treadmill, but in absolute service to player agency. Larian Studios took the chaotic, magnificent spirit of Dungeons & Dragons and rendered it with systemic integrity, solving the decades-old issue of the illusion of choice that plagues the modern RPG genre. The triumph here is not its narrative, though it’s often compelling, but its terrifying mechanical consistency. The Freedom of Choice One of the reasons why Baldur's Gate 3 is successful is its refusal to treat player choice as a mere series of dialogue prompts. Where other titles offer a tightly curated set of branching paths, Larian delivered a simulated reality governed by D&D 5E's core rules. If a character is meant to be unreachable, they are not protected by an invisible wall; they are simply separated by geometry and elevation, obstacles that can be overcome with a simple Misty Step, an improvised jump, or a strategically placed oil barrel. This systemic fidelity grants players the genuine, unsettling freedom to break the game's intended path, and the underlying code is trusted to calculate the consequence. This is the difference between performative agency (AKA when dialogue leads to the same outcome) and true consequence. This approach generates those singular, emergent moments (like the infamous scene involving Halsin, or the bizarre solutions to dungeon puzzles) that are unique to the player’s session, proving that the digital medium can finally emulate the chaotic collaboration of a tabletop campaign. It sets the standard for interactive design by demonstrating that the designer's job is not to dictate the story, but merely to construct the responsive simulation. The art direction shifts between the grimy, oppressive environments of the Goblin Camp and the breathtaking, bioluminescent splendor of the Underdark, establishing a clear mood for every narrative beat. Crucially, the camera's shift from the isometric viewpoint to the tight, cinematic focus during dialogue acts as a crucial validation mechanism. It signals to the player that their decisions are being treated with the same industrial-scale seriousness as a major pre-scripted cutscene. With two million words of recorded dialogue, the quality is often exceptional—particularly the companion performances, which carry the majority of the game’s emotional load. In a game designed to let you talk, sneak, or murder your way out of every encounter, the quality of the dialogue delivery must be consistent to maintain the player’s immersion in the responsive simulation. The orchestral score, while expertly crafted, serves primarily as an effective, atmospheric support layer, underscoring the player’s action without dominating the soundscape. However, such radical ambition inevitably encounters the untenable volume required to sustain it. While Act I and Act II thrive on a tight, interconnected geography, Act III marks where the simulation’s sheer weight begins to crush the narrative's structure. The urgency of the main plot is utterly contradicted by the administrative load of the finale. The game implicitly requires players to wade through thirty or more hours of companion resolutions, murder mysteries, and urban political intrigue to cash in the emotional and narrative debt accumulated over the previous two acts. Crucially, many vital character moments are tied to the Long Rest mechanic, forcing the player, in a moment of narrative crisis, to repeatedly retreat to camp just to ensure companions receive their overdue emotional cutscenes. In my playthough, this resulted in making the plot's climax feel less like a roaring crescendo and more like an abrupt conclusion following an exhaustive slog through content administration. But, everyone's playthrough is different. This brings us to the uncomfortable truth and that is Baldur's Gate 3 is a profound exception. Larian Studios is privately owned meaning they are allowed the luxury "freedom". A six-year development cycle, an eventual team size of 450, and the ability to fund the game through the success of their previous independent IPs and a long, stable Early Access period is what made Baldur's Gate 3 the game it is today. A game which sold a complete, single-player experience with zero monetisation hooks, simply does not fit the modern spreadsheet. The game’s creation required producing over two million words of voice-acted dialogue and animating hundreds of unique cinematic scenes designed for outcomes only a fraction of players will ever see. For your typical AAA studio, this is not something they would do - they operate on the principle of the Minimum Viable Product, maximising monetisation on predictable, repeatable structural foundations. In the end, Baldur's Gate 3 is an astonishing work of art—a towering monument to the possibilities of player agency. Its flaws are the scars of its own radical ambition, the inevitable trade-off when simulation dares to surpass scripted narrative. It is a masterpiece, not because it is perfect, but because it exposed how far the industry had drifted from simply making great games for the sake of making great games.

I’ve played Baldur’s Gate 3 through at least six full times—ranging from noble good-aligned heroes to full-on villainous Dark Urge runs, and everything in between. Custom characters, origin characters, chaotic choices, and methodical planning—I’ve done it all. And I can confidently say this: Baldur’s Gate 3 is one of the best games I’ve ever played. Every playthrough feels fresh. The amount of reactivity and consequence in the game world is staggering. Characters remember what you’ve done. Entire story arcs twist and transform depending on your choices—not just major ones, but even how you handle small conversations or side quests. You don’t just play a character in this game—you are that character, shaped by your every word and action. The writing is top-tier. Voice acting, storytelling, and emotional depth rival anything you’d find in a big-budget HBO series. The companions are unforgettable, and by the end of each run, you feel genuinely attached to them—whether you love them, hate them, or love to hate them. Gameplay-wise, the turn-based combat is a perfect translation of D&D 5e. It’s tactical, challenging, and highly rewarding. There’s room for creative problem-solving in and out of combat, whether you’re exploding barrels, charming enemies, or leaping across rooftops to gain an edge. Baldur’s Gate 3 isn’t just a great CRPG—it’s a generational game. A high watermark for storytelling, player agency, and replayability. If you’re even remotely a fan of roleplaying games, this is a must-play. Final Verdict: 10/10. An all-time great. I’ll be coming back to this for years.

Can “woke” elements ruin a game? Yes — absolutely. Nearly every character I’ve encountered feels like either a “gayboy” or a “girlboss.” Don’t get me wrong: Larian nailed the mechanics, depth, and freedom of choice. On that front, it’s brilliant. The problem is that modern D&D, and by extension this adaptation, is weighed down by too much cultural baggage. Most of the characters so far are unlikable, and honestly? I’ve killed most of them out of sheer spite. D&D used to feel like a hyper-magical version of LOTR; now it’s more like a group of baristas and activists in cosplay, stripped of any real sense of masculinity or gravitas.

Well, there is much that can be said about Balder's Gate 3, and much of it has already been said. I'll try and give my perspective as to why I find this game so enjoyable, and hopefully it will not just be a regurgitation of what you've already heard. How it is to play At its core, Balder's Gate 3 is a video game. I know.... shocking revelation. But what I mean is that you get to actually play this game - very few events in this game will happen unless you specifically do something. This is not a game you can simply just watch happen. You get to decide what happens - you are essentially the director of the gameplay. It's not a game where you can just spam the X or A button to win. You have to actually play it as if it were a machine you are operating. See, this is something that I feel like a lot of modern video games are doing a terrible job at - there are many games out there where you could get the experience they offer just by watching someone else play them or just by watching their cutscenes. The gameplay is so minute that it is more or less a means to end to tell a story. Balder's Gate 3 is not like that. In the same way that I can replay Resident Evil 4 multiple times, Balder's Gate 3 offers the same kind of gameplay experience. There is so much variety, and it largely depends on what, you, the player choose to do. What class you pick, how you choose to buff yourself with armor/weapons, what party make-up you choose, what subclasses you pick - the granularity is deep. There is simply too many options available to you, and it's a good thing. You don't have to be a Monk and just punch your way through every conflict. You can be a Bard and buff Lae'zel and have her smack things out of your way. You can be a Wizard and just cast Hypnotic Pattern and make the enemies unable to even attack. You can be a Ranger and relive your days as a Skyrim stealth archer. Speaking of Skyrim, I never understood the love for Bethesda games as they all pretty much offer the same thing: a good template for a video game, but absent of an actual video game - they leave that up to the modding community. Playing Skyrim without mods is like driving 5 mph on a highway. BG3 without mods is like you're going on a roadtrip - you are perfectly comfortable going at the pace you are. And while mods help the gameplay (mostly QoL stuff), I can't say the the vanilla BG3 experience was bad. Hell, most of that 1000 hour playtime I've racked up is me just fooling around in the vanilla game. There's just so much gamey goodness to it that I didn't really feel the need for mods. It reminds me a lot Mass Effect 1, which isn't surprising as BioWare created the first two Balder's Gate games. It's nice that Larian was able to take the experience the previous BG games offered and modernize it. Mass Effect 1 was my go to action RPG experience as I never could get into the original BG games. I used to really like Mass Effect 1 more so than its sequels. But now? BG3 scratches the same itch and more. It feels good to win in fights - especially if you just barely make it. I know turn-based combat turns off a lot of people, but I would argue BG3 does it right. And it's not even a new system. Final Fantasy X essentially uses the same battle system: turn order displayed, you can delay your opponents from attacking, you can debuff and buff your enemies/allies to turn the turn-order to your advantage and so on. It feels like I am bringing up a lot of different games to compare BG3 to, so how about another: Metal Gear Solid. Sneaking is actually a really useful aspect of combat. You can see your enemies' cones of vision while sneaking, so you can better set your party up to initiate combat at an advantage. It does remind me of playing the original MGS and just watching the radar to make sure I wasn't gonna stumble into a guard's sight. And much like how in MGS3 where you could throw food or animals at guards to distract/kill them, you can do similar actions or spells in BG3 that achieve the same effect. BG3 is a combination of many different games, and I would say: it took all their good parts and exacerbated them. I am struggling to come up with something about this game that holds it back. There's some minor gameplay grudges (like not being able to set up a default hotbar organization for future playthroughs, or not being able to edit the appearances of Origin characters, or how Act 3 is over-loaded with a bit too much content for players to do and not get exhausted - could be a good thing I guess), but I have had more fun playing this game in the past year or so than most other games. And I say all this without even addressing the story - much has been said about the performances of this game, so I won't go into too much detail, but I will say this: this game manages to pull off what the Mass Effect trilogy epicly failed to do: deliver a satisfying conclusion to a player-choice-driven gameplay experience that is all tied up in a nice bow. And it did it with just one game. That's impressive. While we could nitpick certain characters for not being well-developed or used appropriately (Wyll, Halsin, Minsc), all-in-all, what is here is satisfying. I recommend this game if you find yourself pining for a true video game experience that isn't just cutscene spam or just press to X to win. If you like making choices and having them matter, this is a game you need to play. If you like customizing your experience however you want, this is the game to play. After nearly 400 hours in Baldur’s Gate 3, I can confidently say it’s the best game I’ve played in years. Few titles manage to blend graphics, dialogue, and deep companion relationships with such flawless precision. Every choice feels meaningful. Every conversation carries weight. The level of detail in the world design, from the smallest piece of dialogue to the grandest cinematic moment, is nothing short of extraordinary. The companions aren’t just party members; they feel alive, with real personalities, evolving arcs, and emotional depth. The voice acting is phenomenal, the writing rivals high-end fantasy novels, and the graphics bring the Forgotten Realms to life in breathtaking detail. Even after hundreds of hours, I’m still discovering new interactions and storylines I missed before. That’s how rich and layered this game is. Simply put, Baldur’s Gate 3 isn’t just a game it’s an experience. A true benchmark for storytelling and player agency in modern RPGs.

One of my top three games I've ever played, this is coming from someone that has never touched another game in this genre previously and was initially skeptical of trying it during it's initial hype. At it's core it's a top down turn based roleplay RPG, containing a majority of the classes from Dungeons & Dragons, you get to make a highly personalized character with the myriad of presented customization options, of which you can get even more with the plenty of community made mods. Without getting into any spoilers, the story and world building are really good, you meet many great characters throughout your playthrough, for which you are giving the choice to add them into your party. Every character has interesting and seperately unique personalities, they all have different interpersonal relationships between eachother and at times butt heads with one another. Your choices throughout your playtrough influence the character development of your companions, depending on what you choose to do they can end up being a whole different person at the end of the story. Since your choices influence the development of the story, Baldur's Gate 3 has immense replayability, containing many different endings and a lot of things scattered throughout the map, which you will probably miss during your first playthrough. Even if you are thorough with your exploration, there are still things you can easily miss, only to discover them during your second or third time playing. I wholeheartedly recommend playing this game, if you have any semblance of taste in video games, I guarantee you will not regret spending a single cent of the money you put down on this game.

Хорошо проработаны напарники (комедийные напарники Джахейра и Минск - отличные камео к прошлым частям). Бои сбалансированы. Но... Сюжет - одна сплошная рельса. - Хоть что делай, но всё равно придётся сражаться (зачем тогда броски кубика перед финальной битвой?). - И шипастая игрушка (астральная призма) нагло прыграет в руки, когда отказываешь брать Шадоухарт в отряд (логичнее наоборот: все напарники остаются с ней, так как у неё защита). - и другие случаи. Полно явных решений, которых почему-то в игре нет. Т.е. я хочу сказать, что Ларианцы не дотянули до японских РПГ (да и старых западных), когда плохая концовка возникает из-за того, что в начале выбрал не ту девочку. It's ok. It's quite a lot overhyped for what it is, most praising it for things that should be the standard but have been allowed NOT to be the standard. RPG mechanic-wise it is probably one of the best games of it's genre of the recent years. RP-wise, you are still quite heavily railroaded, and the further into the game You go the worse it gets. Most of the characters are also 'ok', and only 'ok'. It's still a far cry from the writing of old RPG games, and modern writers (including BG3 ones) only in theory know what the word 'subtlety' or 'nuance' means. Also related: For people that think that romance paths are well written and 'not bad' in this game, go out into the real world sometimes, talk with an actual human being. Just to have some kind of comparison of how natural human interactions and relationships actually work. Again - subtlety, patience, build-up are words modern writers seemed to only see written down, but never understood the meaning of. The stat roll mechanics that the majority of the game is built upon loses any meaning almost immediately, since the game is just built for save-scumming. Not in a way that just allows it but in a way that if You don't then You can just miss on content, since bad rolls do not push You into an original and unique path, as much as they can just lock You out of things. I purchased the game after it was 'finished' and after it left EA, and tbh I feel scammed when it comes to that. Cause the game was blatantly NOT finished at the time, and it still doesn't seem to be. It's PLAYABLE, not FINISHED. Most might be happy that the game still gets support and patches and content updates - I am not. What I was expecting is the CONTENT of the game is finalized. That when I finally choose to play it, that this is it. It was not. Parts of the game that I played has been changed time and time again, the mechanics, the design was changed and tweaked. That's not maintenance, that's not patching the game to work as intended, it's not debugging. That's DEVELOPMENT. Something that I was led to believe was finalized at the time of the purchase, and yet most (although not all) customers are fine with just because they're used to being treated worse, and because the dev has put himself as the opposition to the trash that happens on the market. It is still a product though - it's better than AVERAGE, it's LESS of a false marketing than usual. It still WAS false marketing to release it as a finished product. And Yeah, my saves after quitting it for a longer time until they get the patches further HAVE broken because of the patches. Can't wait for the game to be FINISHED and stop getting CHANGED so I can start a new playthrough of a non-Early Access build. 8/10. In a world of blind, the one-eyed is the king.

Reviewing before I finish this game, although I doubt anything will change in regards to my feelings for this game. I'll try to not repeat anything that's already been said about BG3, although that will be difficult. This is truly Game of the Year material, and it deserved every single award it has garnered since it's release. It is a role-players heaven, even moreso if you're a fan of DnD. The freedom to approach almost any situation in any way you want is a breath of fresh air: Want to talk a boss into offing themselves? Sure, roll for deception. Want to pickpocket an item from an NPC and then tell them to give it to you only to realise you've stolen it from them and have them fight you? Sure. Want to stuff a backpack full of explosives, throw it on the ground before the fight and then shoot it at the start to literally obliterate everyone in the vicinity? Go ahead. The world, although not a true open world since moving between regions happens on a linear path, is so rich and filled with genuinely interesting stuff. No mind numingly boring fetch quests, no arbitrary collectables that only serve to pad the game, no nothin. Someone can play the entire game and realise they've missed like a dozen quests or a dozen locations cause they just did not notice them. The combat feels rewarding, especially when you get to higher levels and can execute some amazing strategies. It's also very freeing being able to approach combat in any way you want, through using the environment, to using dialogue, through combining different skills and items. There hasn't been a single encounter where I felt frustrated, instead, if I got my ass handed to me, I just thought of new ways to approach the encounter, which the game encourages you to do by giving you hints in the form of books, notes, dialogue etc. There are some less than stelar things like the presence of some bugs or the fact that some companions' quests and general character are less interesting than others, but I digress, these aren't such big issues at the end of the day. This game truly feels like a game adaptation of very captivating DnD campaign. And even if you haven't even played DnD before, this game is one of the most enjoyable TBRPGs out there, hell, it's one of the best RPGs out there period. The depth of the choices and their consequences really reminds me of New Vegas, which also makes me sad that these types of fleshed out games are so few and far between. The sheer amount of dialogue lines this game has is astonishing, and the way the NPCs react to your party's deeds and your own choices is very interesting. The game is also -as of writing this review- 100% feature complete. The final update just released and delivered what some games would charge 20 and 30 euros for, completely for free. This game has no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ microtransactions, no overpriced DLC, no season passes, nothing. You pay 60 euros and you get around 80-100 hours of your first playthrough, plus endless potential for replayability and co-oop of up to 4 players! These are the types of developers people should support, people that care about crafting good experiences, people that value the player's time and money. Hats off Larian, you beautiful bastards. It'll be ages before we get an RPG quite like BG3.
This game is absolutely fantastic. It's so refreshing not to be bombarded with micro-transactions in a full priced game. Larian really knocked it out of the park! :D

There’s also a ton of freedom in how you approach situations—sneaking, talking your way out, going full chaos, whatever fits your playstyle. The companions are amazing. Each one has their own backstory, personality, and they feel like real people. I ended up caring about all of them, even the ones I didn’t think I’d like at first. Visually, the game looks great too. The environments are beautiful, the character animations during cutscenes are top-notch, and the voice acting is some of the best I’ve heard in any RPG. If you like D&D, story-rich RPGs, or just games that give you a lot of freedom, definitely give this one a shot. Easily one of the best games I’ve played in a long time.

Now some complaints. While the story overall is very good, some story elements aren't the best. Act 1 clearly got more love than Act 3, making some things fall flat, but there is literally so much game here I understand why it didn't get as much attention near the end, especially due to time constraints. Some parts of the story had rewrites and you can tell they aren't as strong. They game is also incredibly buggy, which I honestly just expect from AAA games at this point, but my game was so bugged that literally every playthrough is just different due to different bugs. Characters sometimes didn't express story stuff to be that led to confusing but funny scenarios, for example My PC bluescreened at least twice during my playthrough, and crashed many more. My PC was built in 2022 with all the latest tech available at the time, it is not a baby, it really shouldn't be having issues so I can only blame the game. Also the final battle was the most bugged thing ever which really killed the immersion. Despite those few complaints, I really do love this game. I do understand some of the bugs, like there are so many branching story options and voice lines recorded for extremely niche scenarios that are so fun to find. Also most of the bugs were more funny than the frustrating for the most part. If I could wipe it from my brain to play blindly over again I would. Definitely one of my favorite games out there.

I can confidently say that Baldur's Gate 3 is one of the best RPGs ever made. Larian Studios has delivered a game that blends epic storytelling, deep gameplay, and unmatched freedom. The writing is phenomenal, with choices that truly matter and unforgettable characters like Astarion and Shadowheart, whose personalities and backstories draw you in completely. The turn-based combat is tactical and rewarding, but what truly sets the game apart is its creativity—solving problems with diplomacy, stealth, or even throwing someone off a cliff is entirely up to you. Add stunning visuals, a meticulously crafted world, and a gorgeous soundtrack, and you have a fully immersive experience that redefines what RPGs can achieve. With incredible replayability thanks to branching storylines and countless approaches to situations, Baldur's Gate 3 is the new gold standard for the genre and an absolute must-play.

BG3 is a very challenging game to review... It has near universal acclaim and therefore feels untouchable; it sucks you in and fits an old D&D player like a glove. It's amazing to really push the adapted 5e ruleset to its limits and imagine all your worst minmaxxed fears, but this is sadly also where it starts breaking down. There are a few running bugs that occur often unless you have 3rd party assistance - I had to cap the fps to 60 or risk the game crashing every 5 minutes (Thanks Reddit) and even so, crashes abound. Sneak, stealth and surprise are all bugged and non-intuitive - they often require you to bypass the turnbased nature of the game to realise, which makes them unusable in most instances. Multiclassing often bugs base class features or requires you to class in a certain order for them to work, (Thanks again Reddit.) And in one instance, a multiclass rogue/ranger had none of its base class features proc, ever. (Thanks to posters on Larian's own forums for running a 2 year long thread pointing this one out.) All in all though, the average player or non-D&D player will quite likely never encounter most of these and have a blast. The story gets a 10/10 for inventiveness and last minute second guessing; but a 1/10 for replayability due to relying heavily on surprise - so just roll 4 Fighters into a party, minmax them for combat and smash your way through - who needs all that fancy dialog afterall. If I could give a 50/100, I would, but Steam needs a Yay or Nay - all in all, I still enjoyed the hell out of it, even though it often frustrated me beyond words, so I'll mark it a yes. Please just make more adventures. Don't need a BG4, just fix the basic bugs in the engine and roll out more stories - CoS, ToA, DtA will all be amazing to experience in this setting and all start in Baldurs Gate, so no need to recreate it. D&D is a system with which to explore worlds, you have the system, now bring the worlds or it all fails

Baldur’s Gate 3 is a triumph of storytelling, character depth, and gameplay mechanics that manages to appeal even to those who may not typically enjoy top-down strategy or tactical games. As someone who doesn't usually gravitate toward the genre, my love for Dungeons & Dragons tipped the scales, and I'm thrilled it did. From the moment you dive into the world, the game feels alive, rich with lore, and dripping with choices that matter. The narrative depth is staggering, allowing for endless possibilities based on player decisions. The voice acting, dialogue, and character interactions breathe life into every encounter, making you feel like you're living through a tabletop campaign with all the dramatic flair and humor you’d expect. The gameplay might initially feel daunting for newcomers to tactical combat or D&D-inspired systems. However, the combat system is intuitive, with plenty of flexibility for creativity. Whether you're leaping across the battlefield, shoving enemies into environmental hazards, or casting spells with devastating or hilarious effects, the game encourages you to think outside the box. Visually, Baldur’s Gate 3 is stunning. The environments are crafted with incredible detail, and the character models are expressive, ensuring that the emotional weight of your decisions lands effectively. Combined with the stirring soundtrack, the game becomes an immersive experience that’s hard to put down. What sets this game apart for someone like me is how faithfully it captures the spirit of D&D. The freedom to approach problems in your unique way, the genuine consequences for your actions, and the opportunity to build a party of quirky, flawed, and lovable characters all reflect the heart of the tabletop experience. Baldur’s Gate 3 might not convert every non-strategy fan, but it’s an undeniable masterpiece that rewards players willing to step out of their comfort zones. For fans of D&D, it’s a must-play—an epic adventure worthy of its legendary name.

10/10 Larian took everything they have learned about RPGs from their previous games and gave a masterpiece. This is the closest you can get to playing D&D as a videogame. The maps are very open and huge, allowing you to take the story however you want. An epic tale intertwining characters both old and new, they did the franchise justice. Local split screen - Play it with someone!! No loot boxes. No micro transactions. No live service model. No paid dlc - everything they released after launch was free. They refused to make a sequel or add-on because their team was burned out. Years of post-launch support both fixing and adding things the players wanted. This is what we should expect from the gaming industry. Bravo, Larian. Bravo!

5 Playthroughs, almost 500 hours in game, and lots of fun later and I still don't feel like I've seen/done everything this game has to offer. If you haven't bought this game, you're just plain missing out. Based on D&D but made accessible by playing like a movie, this game is the closest you can get to a sit down tabletop adventure with friends in videogame form. Except, your friends are all extremely talented voice-actors, and you can do the story over again and make different choices to get different outcomes. Or, hell, why not just play the game WITH your friends instead of NPCs? The game's outcomes are based on your decisions and whether your friends choose something you like or something you don't, chances are you'll get a completely different adventure because of it. TL;DR: if you haven't at least tried this game, what're you doing with your life?

First time in a very long time I've been this excited for a new release. So many lately have been overhyped, overmarketed, overpromised and ultimately lacking. Day 1 DLC, game breaking bugs, some that even cooked graphics cards. It's satisfying that I bought a game that feels complete start to finish. It's normal to have some bugs on a game release. There's no such thing as the perfect game, even when looking back through the nostalgia glasses, so it's not the expectation of perfection. It's the expectation of enjoyment and functionality without having to worry about microtransactions, time wasters, live service, and all of the other baggage that goes along with most releases these days. And this game by no means is completely unique in that regard, we've seen a couple that have been like that, and they deserve the same praise. The story is solid from start to end, and the largest complaint I could have about any specific section wasn't the content of the section but that I wanted more of it. Wanting to follow questlines to their fullest, wanting to explore minor characters more fully and just be further immersed in the writing and *effort* put in. How so many references are a love letter to the previous Baldur's Gate games and Faerun in general but also expands upon those things further, becoming its own thing in its own way. How it can make references to lore entirely outside the scope of the game, and make it meaningful but not devastating to those that don't know that lore. The gameplay is also satisfying. It uses 5e as a base, but makes several incredibly important changes that work very well for the nature of a video game (and quite frankly some of them would be good for our tabletop game as well). The rebalance of certain features (or entire class, as the monk goes) works well, making thus far every class I have tried across custom characters and origin characters feel impactful. Having a philosophy of fun over balance, but still maintaining genuine difficulty with many of the encounters is a masterstroke. Beyond that we have the options available at any given point. In past crpgs we all experienced the severe limitations of how to complete the quests. That didn't make them bad; I loved the Neverwinter series, the Baldur's series to this point, and both pathfinder games from owlcat. They're all games to be lauded and appreciated, being those that came before and the building blocks for those that came after. And build Larian did. Having played both DOS games and seeing the progression from one to the next not only in engine but in story scope. Rare in the old days could you take a quest and complete it in a completely different way. A few times per game. Now I've found that rare are the times where there is only one solution. While these types of games will never have the modularity and freedom of a tabletop game, this is the closest that gaming has gotten to it. In reference to those twitter threads, reddit posts, and memes galore- Larian raised the bar. You may not like it, but it's happened.
