I am 78. My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old. When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide. After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side. Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay. After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as. Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends. I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together. Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that. Thank you.

Great game, and probably the most influential one in the past decade for CRPGs. It can probably serve as a good entry to the genre for most people. In typical Larian fashion, the game starts out great, but loses steam toward the end. The good: - Probably the best companions the genre has to offer in the past decade. - Unmatched voice acting. - An amazing soundtrack. - Excellent Act 1–Act 2. - Cutting-edge graphics. - Good reactivity; you truly feel like the game reacts to your choices. - A faithful adaptation of DnD 5e. The bad: - The UI and everything about it. It feels clunky, near-impossible to play without mods. The camera gets in the way, the characters move around randomly sometimes, stepping into traps. Submenus in submenus. Some things feel purposefully hidden, like multiclassing. - OPENING EVERY CHEST takes ages. - About 60% of the game is just getting from point A to B with horrible controls. - WAITING in combat: sometimes you have to wait a good 2 minutes until every enemy acts out their turn. - DnD 5e is not a good system, in my opinion. Sure, it works as an entry to the CRPG genre, but it's nowhere near as good for storytelling as Pathfinder 1e, for example. - Act 3 feels really disjointed. - Act 3 brings back loads of characters from the previous entries (BG1–2) but doesn't do them justice. In fact, that's probably the weakest part of the game. (besides the terrible UI) - The itemization is weak. Some items are interesting, but nowhere near as game-changing as in other CRPGs.

Not my favorite combat compared to Larian's previous title, Divinity Original Sin 2, which made me feel like every single action had a good snap to it. Here in Baldur's Gate 3, however, there is a high miss rate for you and your enemies, which made me feel more like "eh whatever" rather than being engaged and frustrated in a good way (which is what I get from my hundreds of hours playing XCOM Long War 2, probably a good example of a good combat with a lot of miss). The overarching plot isn't that deep or reflective, but it doesn't hurt either. The first cutscene of the game already establishes a good sense of urgency, plus a strong reason that binds you to the other main characters of the story. The first 20 hours were incredible. I felt like I was getting big emotional moments akin to Chrono Trigger and Mass Effect 2 at a much higher pace than those games. However, BG3 does eventually start to drag and lose the magic due to many big maps (that are excessively big for no reason) and a big amount of characters that, while good for the extra content, often doesn't impact the game in any meaningful way. That's when it hit me that Chrono Trigger and Mass Effect 2 are still above this. So, I guess the best way to play this game is to ignore quests and just focus on roleplaying, which makes perfect sense when you take into account how you can always come back to any area you want and that many of the rewards doesn't do much (so logically, your character building isn't threatened at all from simply playing the game) Overall, I'm satisfied for the first 20 hours, which were unforgettable for me, and I appreciate the work put into cutscenes, voice acting and character building. Is this my favorite game? No. Does this beat the RPG experience of vanilla Skyrim? I don't think so. But still, I'm glad this game exists.

Hard to understand how this won so many awards. In my opinion, it is a terrible GAME. Which is to say, the mechanics of the video game itself, built around a psuedo-5e ruleset, are among the worst of any video game I've ever played in 30+ years of gaming (including playing DOS games as a child). Camera controls are horrible. I spent 8 hours constantly wrestling with framing my characters and the battle maps so I could effectively see what was going on. You can't zoom out as far as you would want to. Bumping the side of the screen immediately disables the camera lock on a character, which you then you have to re-enable with a key bind or menu. Movement controls are infuriating. Click to move makes no sense when you're not in combat. Why in gods name they decided not to allow WASD or joystick movement out of combat...I have no idea. I've never played a Larian Studios game before, so perhaps this is the standard, but it's terrible. In my 8 hours of gameplay, at least half of it was mis-clicking. Either moving a character I didn't want to move or using an ability I didn't want to use or using an item I didn't want to use. If you are in any way familiar with DnD rules, particularly 5e, you will find this game annoying. It is not a benefit to have previous experience with DnD, in fact, it is a liability. For obvious reasons, they could not simply import 5e rules 1:1. Those rules were designed for a TTRPG not a video game. There are a myriad of SLIGHT changes to familiar rules which will result in consistent unexpected consequences to mundane decisions. Everything from what qualifies as a Bonus Action, to how long a spell/effect lasts, to the resource cost of spells and effects are just SLIGHTY different enough to require you to relearn an entire new set of gamerules. Obviously, that's not terribly different from playing ANY new video game, but it does mean that if you have 5e knowledge and habits, you have to UNLEARN them before you can learn the game. Finally, my biggest complaint about gameplay is the lack of clarity when it comes to the consequences of dialogue choices and combat actions. It is very easy to make a decision you believe to be mundane only to find it has far reaching consequences. Dialogue options are locked in, which of course they are, it would be impossible to create a video game that can anticipate any and every line of dialogue a player might want to use. However, unlike an RPG game like Knights of the Old Republic, the options presented to you give no indication as to the direction the line of dialogue is going (for example: Polite, Rude, Insulting, etc). The dialogue options simply list what skill you are using, but Persuasion has a myriad of intentions and result. As the game does not have a human DM that you can argue your case with, nor does it have a simple way of undoing an action (outside of Save Scumming, which is neither fast nor easy), I ended up repeatedly making "decisions" I had no intention of choosing that were not in line with the character I was trying to emulate and suffering negative consequences as a result. While playing a Paladin, I attempted to save Lazael from a brother-sister pair of tieflings who were intent on killing her because "she's a demon". In other words, they think she's dangerous because she is an alien (githyanki) and they erroneously believe her to be dangerous. Understandable and typical. Nothing wrong with the scenario. However, the paladin dialogue option results in a fight, and if you kill or knock one of them unconscious you are branded an OATHBREAKER. For protecting an innocent from a murderous misunderstanding. This would never happen at the table top, because you would be able to explain the situation and argue your case with the DM. You do not have this option in the game. Instead, you only have the option as a Paladin to attempt a DECEPTION roll. Beyond frustrating. It resulted in the loss of hours of gameplay, as I did not have a save state since the crash. I'm sure the rest of the game is as everyone says it is: filled with hundreds of hours of fantastic voice overs, rich story, and deep lore. But they certainly don't make it easy to GET there. Just one man's opinion, one that is clearly not widely held. EDIT: I forgot to mention that my complaints are repeatedly met with "just MOD it" or "there's a MOD that fixes that". That's nice. I personally don't mod my video games. I prefer to play them vanilla. I also think that the base video game should be playable WITHOUT mods. In fact, I don't think that is a very high bar to set. Mods should add content to a game, not fix glaring issues. Again, just one man's opinion.

However, other than that I feel it is at least worth trying if you're looking for a game to sink your teeth into. If you have gotten to the year of our lord 2025 without playing this then you are eating good this year. Being able to experience this for the first time in a year with many other amazing releases would be a damn good position to be in. Finish Oblivion Remaster and Claire Obscur then pick this up easy peasy. Naturally, if you're a fan of the Divinity franchise then this game will also offer you a lot. As Larian has certainly carried over some DNA. Though the combat system may take some adjusting, especially considering it is a common criticism I see from DOS veterans when talking about this game.With that in mind, I still find the DnD 5E implementation here to be very fun overall. And it is still a turn based isometric rpg, obviously. So Im sure it will still scratch that itch for fans even if you may find the implementation worse than Divinity overall. With all of that said, now that we are at the end of the content cycle for this game it just seemed like an appropriate time to give my thoughts on the game. And thats basically all this review its, as there is little detail. Just me glazing the game up and down for a few paragraphs. So give it a try if you havent already. If you have and its not your cup of tea, thats ok. But, for me, it has cemented its place as my favorite game of all time. And is one that I would easily recommend.

A good DM wouldn't design a fight where your players get stun locked and there's nothing they can do about it. A medicore DM would design the encounter, but would fudge the numbers if they realized their players weren't having fun with the encounter, maybe even cut it short. A bad DM would design the encounter, keep the rolls straight, let the party get TPKed and end the campaign just like that. This game being based around 5e's system made me think that it'd be a fun experience similar to DND. But without the DM there to actually contextualize actions past their baseline interpretation, the game very quickly loses that aspect. I can understand if Halsen, wildshaped into a bear, thinks we're going to leave him to the goblins and becomes hostile towards us. But once we use him breaking free as a distraction - stopping and One and Three from going to get reinforcements, killing the rest of the goblins, never once attacking him directly - you'd think he'd realize "oh, these guys are actually helping me!", and drop the hostility... But of course, such a stupid idea is one that only a DnD player could come up with. I would know, I'm not only a player myself, but also a DM! So of course without a DM he just remains hostile on us. But if we do non-lethal damage, maybe we can just knock him out and drag him to the Cove? Nope! You knock him out - again, NON LETHAL DAMAGE - and the game fails the quest and acts like you killed him! Okay, fine, whatever. It is what it is. Can't account for all possible routes of stupidity when you're making a game this open ended. But you have to at least BALANCE it. You can't expect a party of 4 at best to actually Want to fight off an entire goblin army, so give them a way to avoid that. Gut lets you do that! You can lure her into her room and kill her without the rest of the Goblins noticing. The other 2 goblin leaders, the hobgoblin and the drow lady - you can't do that. So how are you expected to kill the leaders without Alerting the Hoard like you bumped the pixel of a car in L4D? You simply Don't. You go back to the cove and you rest and you warn them the next day and you make your players feel stupid because there's genuinely no other option that doesn't incite a war. And then there's Auntie Ethel. Sweet innocent bog hag Ethel. Who can duplicate herself up to SIX DIFFERENT TIMES, and EACH DUPLICATION ACTS AS ITS OWN ENTITY. They don't share resources, concentration, actions - NOTHING. The party size is capped at 4. Now you might just say "erm the dupes disappear after one hit just attack them 5head." Okay wise guy I'll do that when I get out of this Hold Person. Except I can't because the moment I do Ethel #5 puts me in another one. So you just sit there and watch as your whole party gets STUNLOCKED and pissed on with poison spray.

Solid 7/10 I know that many people absolutely love this game. However, there are quite a few things I personally didn’t enjoy, and it often feels like most players prefer to focus only on the positive side of game. Let’s start with the pros: a huge world, a wide variety of game mechanics, strong replay value, and good optimization. Larian has clearly put a lot of effort into this game, and it will probably be remembered for many years. Players will keep replaying it and finding new things every time. Now for the cons. Everything written below is purely my personal opinion, and you may disagree with it. Maybe this is part of Larian’s signature style, but Baldur’s Gate 3 constantly puts the player in front of difficult and often dumb choices. Sometimes these choices feel so absurd that I just want to make no decision at all and close the game. Very often, you’re forced to choose between two dumb outcomes - for example, between your own death or letting someone else die in a much worse way, while knowing that you might get testicular cancer. Sometimes during dialogues, you have to pass several skill checks, and since this is a DnD-based game, you can easily fail them even if your skill level is high. This isn’t exactly a downside. It’s actually one of the game’s strengths. But if you’re on a second playthrough and want to get a different outcome from a quest, this can make things quite frustrating. Throughout the game, you meet characters with their own personal motives. From the start, some of them clearly show that they want to use you or might even harm you. At the same time, you can’t really do much about it, because they are important to the main story. You’re basically forced to go along with it and let these characters act however they want. The same problem applies to companions. If you choose not to help a companion with their personal quest, or if you solve it in a way they don’t like, they can get offended, leave your party, or even attack you. In some cases, characters may become hostile or distance themselves from you even if you genuinely try to help. This isn’t really about gratitude or morality. The game has many deep and well-designed systems, and NPCs can react differently depending on your actions and the situation. Still, there are moments when their reactions feel incredibly stupid or completely unpredictable, especially when you expect something more logical.

Come sempre la critica fa il suo lavoro in maniera pessima, leggo di voti come 80,90 o 95 per questo titolo. L'opera di Larian studio è da 100 senza alcun tipo di compromesso, i "difetti" elencati sono tutti risolvibili tramite patch e sono cose che NON compromettono l'esperienza del videogiocatore on nessun modo. L'industria videoludica si divide in giochi fatti veramente bene ma recensiti male e in maniera oggettiva e giochi con mappe nemici e meccaniche riciclate che vanno avanti grazie al loro nome e ai pareri sempre oggettivi dei recensori. Baldur's gate 3 offre una libertà immensa con diversissimi modi per arrivare al finale (ben 17000 modi diversi), il combattimento a turni e coinvolgente è presenta chicche interessanti (ad esempio altezza e peso vengono considerati così da far stordire il nemico o farlo cadere magari in un pavimento crepato), l'ambiente circostante è un elemento da tenere sempre d'occhio durante i combattimenti dato che possono esserci elementi che danno vantaggio al nostro avventuriero (come:barili,oggetti sospesi fino ad arrivare anche ai tetti dove è possibile arrivare con i ****). Il party è veramente importante parlare con loro è legare porterà solo che vantaggi (oltre che a moltissime romance), ogni run cambierà anche in base al vostro party e alla peculiarità di ogni ****, ad esempio avere un **** con maggior percezione rispetto a noi può portarci a scoprire diversi segreti presenti nella zona di gioco così da condurci a qualche tesoro o qualche sorpresa inaspettata. La personalizzazione del proprio **** è a dir poco fenomenale, si possono fare creazioni in maniera curata e ben dettagliata che vi faranno perdere ore e ore per quanti elementi si possono cambiare a seconda della razza scelta. La trama è piena di spettacolo e di emozioni, ci troviamo nei forgotten realms di D&D, non si sente mai un singolo momento di noia e si respira sempre aria di avventura e magia.Ogni NPC circostante ci può portare sempre a una variazione cosi da far vivere ogni atto in maniera completamente diversa a seconda delle nostre azioni o dell'approccio che abbiamo avuto. Non ho voglia di continuare a scrivere perché sarebbe davvero troppo lungo spiegare tutto ma Baldur's gate 3 è un diamante ben fatto e ben lavorato che porta solo alla perfezione.

"Baldur’s Gate 3 is an outstanding experience from start to finish. The gameplay is engaging, with deep, tactical combat that rewards creativity and smart decision-making. The storyline is equally impressive — rich, immersive, and full of meaningful choices that truly shape the world and your character’s journey. I especially appreciated the attention to detail in the writing, the diverse companions, and the way the game honors the Dungeons & Dragons roots while making it accessible to newcomers. Every playthrough feels unique, and the replay value is huge. My only real gripe is the level cap — I found myself wishing I could progress my character further, especially given how invested I became in their development. That said, it’s a minor complaint in what is otherwise a phenomenal RPG experience. All in all, Baldur’s Gate 3 sets a new standard for narrative-driven RPGs. If you’re a fan of the genre, this is an absolute must-play. 4.7 out of 5!

A brilliant RPG, but not without flaws: As in Larian's previous DOS2, the scale seems to have gotten away from them. I wouldn't wish the game to be any longer than it is, but the third act seems to be half-missing. The expected contrast between criminality and seediness in the lower city with politics and power in the upper city simply isn't there. More importantly, the story seems to have changed between the writing of act I and the completion of acts II and III. The Chekhov gun shown in the first act is never fired. There's a suggestion that the Ilithid powers will cost the player something, but in the end they cost nothing. The game constantly pesters the player to use the tadpoles, and to pester party members to use them in turn, without a definitive option to say one will never do that, not to mention a reward for such action. Large parts of the game are about temptations of power, yet there's never a cost, for any character, for not taking it. The idea is instead introduced and then abandoned. The game isn't difficult enough for the powers to be important, despite the Emperor constantly stating that it is vital. In DOS2 one had to be careful what battles were attempted, here the only way to encounter real difficulty, even on the hardest settings, is to bring an unfamiliar set of companions to one of the bigger boss fights. There are too many companions. We don't really need Halsin, Jaheria and Minsc, who should have come and gone as NPCs. By the time they arrive they can only really sit at camp and provide commentary until the end of the game. Less would have been more. Failure could be made more interesting. Disco Elyisum, itself a mutated adaptation of Dungeons and Dragons, showed how failing a skill check can be just as fun as passing it, but these lessons have not been applied to other games. It would be nice also if the camp had been a bit more fleshed out. Some scenes between companions or variation, as in Mass Effect, would have made it seem more alive, rather than as a place to store companions. The music in the Elfsong Tavern is truly terrible to listen to while trying to sort inventory. As a game that permits a variety of approaches it is quite a success, and this clearly is where the effort went. There are so many different ways to go about things, it's a wonder that things don't break more often, but the bugs that remain are minor. It is nice that there are few "puzzle" battles with single solutions that cannot otherwise be completed. It's remarkably flexible, and very friendly to the player, allowing saving even during dialogue. It was a joy to play (three times!) and I look forward to whatever Larian do next, but I do hope they learn to scale their ambition to what can be done in the time available.

I had the game for about a year before I gave it a real shot. It was not the game I expected it to be when I jumped in. I was hooked! every day I just just couldn't wait to get back to my group and see what would happen next. I made a lot of mistakes with abilities, character builds, and story content....or did I? I ended up playing through the end and Wow wow wow was I blown away with everything packed in BG3. This is a game where you take your time, think about your approach and just have a blast. No game is perfect. Not every game is for everyone, but this game just hit all the right notes for me. I fell in love with the story, the characters, all the story arc's and just about everything else the game threw at me. If I had any complaints, they would be minimal. I may not have had the same opinion if I played it earlier than I did. I started my first play through after patch 8. so maybe I got lucky by having the latest version with most/all of the kinks iron'd out? I'm not a poet or an English major, so the level of praise and the words I want to use to sing praises isn't my strong suit. What I can and will say is that BG3 is on my top 10 all time list forever. I've been playing games since NES, so I've been gaming a long time and this is the kind of game we used to dream about when I was a kid on my 8 bit system wondering what the future of gaming would look like. BG3 is the end product every dev team out there dreams of making no matter what type of game they are producing. the polish, the detail, the love, the ambition! its all here, and its very easy to dive back in on a new game and have a very different experience. So hat's off to Larian Studios for crafting such a wonderful work of art. I never thought this would be a game that I'd sink into for hundred's of hours and come out raving. Cheers if you made it this far into my review. If your on the fence, give it a shot. learn the mechanics, take your time and try out new things! and save, save, save!! 10/10

But, maybe you're like me, confused to why this game is being hailed as the greatest thing ever made, because you've given it hours of your time, when every minute felt like a chore. Maybe like me, you wanted desperately to enjoy this game, but found yourself bored or frustrated, and nothing else while playing it. It could be because you can lose hours of progress to RNG if you don't save scum, it could be you don't particularly enjoy turn-based combat. It could be because after almost 8 hours, you've done nothing whatsoever. I wanted to like this game, I really did. I almost feel weird disliking it, solely because of how beloved it is. But there wasn't a single moment where I enjoyed playing the game. I came away from this feeling completely disconnected from popular opinion, and like there must be something wrong with me for not enjoying it. If you found this negative review in the sea of positive ones, you may feel similarly.

The developers at Larian Studios have created something very special with Baldur's Gate 3. And even if developers of large studios fight tooth and nail against it: This role-playing game sets new standards, and future RPGs will have to be measured against it. It is a video game in its purest form that holds a mirror up to the industry. It shows us how video games used to be and how they should be, something the industry has forgotten far too often. It is a work of art, born from the passion and love of a studio that has not been corrupted by the industry's rampant greed. You can tell in every fiber of Baldur's Gate 3 that it wasn't created to generate maximum revenue. Instead, it is a product of the love for video games that characterizes Creative Director Swen Vincke and his team.

I'm extremely aware that I'm in the minority with this opinion but I thought BG3 was massively overhyped. My main point of reference that I was using when playing this game was Wrath of the Righteous, which I consider to be a much better game (although this opinion is also shared by few). Constantly, as I was going through the game, I kept finding myself saying 'this wasn't an issue in WotR'. Like, how the game takes the modifier from your currently selected character rather than the highest among the party. Or the limited party size punishing you for playing your own character instead of one of the pre-made ones. Or how the game is based on 5e DnD, which I consider to be a system so flawed, you have to Ship of Theseus the whole thing in order to get it to function well (which this game does do but I feel it would've been better if they used an entirely different system altogether). And these are just a few examples, although most other ones I have are admittedly much more nitpicky, but they just kept piling up the longer I played. To be frank, I think the vast majority of people like this game because of its production value. I've also had a few friends play this and WotR and even admit that they couldn't get into WotR because the production value was much lower and that said production value carried BG3 hard. The characters were pretty good but that feeds into my criticism about the limited party size. I don't wanna play Shadowheart or Karlach, I wanna play my own guy! And the game punishes you for doing that because one of its best features IS the characters themselves, so playing it the way I want to makes the game objectively worse, which left such a bad taste in my mouth, I'd rather they not even give the option in the first place to play your own guy. If you get this game, I am absolutely certain you will enjoy it. But I just, can't get behind it at all. I like WotR to much to like BG3. Product received for free TLDR: Yes the game is good, would recommend if you have several dozen hours of spare time. Baldur's Gate 3 is essentially a 3-way between a romance sim, a tactical RPG, and a storybook. All of which is wrapped in a beautiful bow of a variety of features and play-styles. Now if one of those feels out of place of the three, then you'd be right. We'll get to that when we get to it. Nevertheless, the game was constantly updated and clearly a passion project rather than something done for pure profit. There is a reason why the game took so long to release the full state and even then why they kept updating it some often passed its original release. Now that no more 'significant' updates are supposed to be released I feel it is comfortable for me to share my thoughts and story. DISCLAIMER - I got this game as a gift from my friends, which means I have 0 dollars paid. So this review although I hope can inform you about what I thought of the game and how I personally enjoy or not enjoy it (and will include spoilers) it will likely not tell you if the game is worth $70.00 USD. So I hope that this can be just one piece of information you can turn to for assistance in the decision making process to purchase BG3. PROS Let's state with Character Customization. This game has a lot of it. like A LOT. You can see within the first few minutes of what make your character look like from their clothes, skin, class, gender (which has multiple options good on you Larian), and even what kinds of backgrounds you can be. These options allow you to make the character YOU want and how YOU will tell the story. Since the game doesn't use voice for the main character Tav they are just a self insert. They gotta have some personality given to them, so you have plently of oppurtunity to do that. Now Character Customization also includes choosing your class as alluded to. Since this is a video game rather than actual D&D multi-classing becomes a lot more viable and silly. So many of the most absurd builds that (mostly) use the game's fun jank can be built with little effort on your part. Especially, since everyone can have their class changed or other aspects redistributed via Withers. The 5e system in the game (which ties into both the above and bottom points) is a variant on D&D 5th edition, specifically the 2014 rules. They have made some minor changes to certain abilities and spells that are barely noticible. The bigger changes are to the way class advancements work. But some classes (like warlock) suffer at higher levels due to a lack of increases. Instead they make slight modifications to subclasses to make them more optimal than their D&D counterparts. This is very apprent in their recent Arcane Archer addition. The side content is everywhere. A nook, a cranny, a random interaction with a shovel. They are everywhere. Onto the CONS You may have noticed something about the cons, they are all about the writing in the game. Before I get into it I'll give some positive thoughts about the game that relate to the writing but not really the writing itself. The narrator is very fun (despite it not being Kevin Michael Richardson like from BG1 & some of BG2). The actual voice acting is bloody amazing, literally every performance is oozing with charm and it is clear that some of the actors studied up for the rolls to get the right accents for some character such as Matt Mercer doing a mighty good impression of Jim Cummings which still being himself. With the voice actors out of the way onto the actual problems. The narrative is lazy. Yes you heard that right, lazy. For a game that was hyped up for being the #1 D&D sim, that will be like playing D&D at home and having fun and learning secrets. Every twist and turn is a 'why?' or a 'duh'. I will summarize the entire BG3 narrative without spoilers you ready? 1. You have object, someone wants object and hunts you for it 2. Object revealed to be secret weapon against big evil 3. You use power obtained from object to defeat big evil Finally... the romance thing. Look, I understand you want everyone to feel included. But the likelihood of everyone in the room being pan & wanting to bang is pretty unlikely. For a romance to work it needs to be something you have to strive or work towards. There is no work involved with these relationships, they are just there. Although you could say this is an issue with gaming at the whole at the moment, BG3 is just the most noticeable since well bigger audience. I hope this helps someone somewhere. This game is fun, just sometimes a pain for someone invested in the series.

I’m really torn writing this review. I’ve seen the acclaim and figured I need to try. And it took about 20h and two tries for me to get in to this game. And by hour 35 and the end of Act 2, I “got it”. The story was building. I loved my party. Choices felt impactful. I felt powerful.  And then there’s Act 3. I spent 15 more hours hitting walls and just not getting it. “Hurry Up!…oh wait, you’re under leveled so figure out the mail system. Then hurry up! Like. The world literally ends today!”  Larian did such a good job avoiding one of my least favorite issues with open world games - the “get it done now!” Plot running headlong in to the “but first, I want to learn how to craft pottery”plot. It’s jarring. Some people don’t mind. If you don’t, great! If you do, you’ll hate Act 3.  Finally, I read some “played it a while” reviews and I felt heard. Hundreds of people agreed. Something just changes in Act 3 and the game becomes nothing more than tying up loose ends you started earlier … with whimpering conclusions. Your party stops talking to you. Plots get confused and dialog starts making assumptions that aren’t true. All that immersion felt…was gone.  And that ***** because Larian absolutely made the closest thing to a table top game I’ve ever played. The systems. The flexibility. The hundreds of dialog branches. Did you remember to speak to the dead? Or maybe close a door? Those seemingly small ripples create waves later.  Until they don’t. And then it’s just a series of battles. Which…I got in the habit of twisting or avoiding. Because. Open ended RPG. And then I couldn’t.  So. That’s my review. Admittedly, I bounced off the third Act after 77 total hours played. I kept trying and trying. And I stopped having fun. And that’s the best rule of any game? Is it a 4 but fun? Have fun playing it! Is it a 10 but not your thing? Don’t play it.  So I stopped. And if some of what I said resonated , you may have to stop too.

Be honest—I bought this game back then mostly because it was insanely popular at the time. I had NO experience with D&D-style games, so when I first started, I had no clue how to create advantages or remove disadvantages. Naturally, I kept getting absolutely destroyed by gnolls DAMNNNNN, which led to me rage quitting and abandoning the game for about two years I think ? Recently, out of sheer boredom or maybe a bit of pride, I decided to come back. After watching a bunch of guide videos and taking advice from people who had already beaten the game, I rebuilt my party into something that actually resembles a functional team. Suddenly, exploration stopped feeling like a survival horror experience(I killed all the gnolls yeahh). I used to rely on F5 and F8 to bend the story into the *correct* timeline—the one where I never fail a roll. But at some point, I decided to accept the dice as they are. If a check fails, it fails. I guess embracing that randomness is part of the game’s charm .. and part of learning to let go of control as a player——just like my life, unfortunately. sad.

So unbelievably overhyped and not at all worth that constant $60 pricetag. Edit if you want an actual response, holy paragraphs Batman. I didn't feel like writing a whole essay for my original review but I already made this response and I think a game like this deserves some elaboration. Don't forget that you are ABSOLUTELY NOT allowed to criticize art in any way, ESPECIALLY not popular art that everyone likes, or that makes you a bad gamer and that's an irredeemable sin. I've actually never liked any video game ever, in fact I hate all of them and wish my hobby would just die already. With that in mind, here's what I dislike about the game: Every character is written with MCU dialogue. Everyone is witty and funny and "we're all going on an adventure team!" and it's so boring. I remember specifically Shadowheart saying "I guess that's what I like about you, you're different." Like seriously? My silent protagonist that has done nothing but stare and pick dialogue option number one the entire time is special? Why? Why am I different, literally tell me what I did, all we've done is battle and talk to people. It's just cringe all around, all the characters are cringe. That one annoying devil that just showed up and kidnapped me, then started speaking in poems as he tried to convince me he "totally didn't want my soul for bad things, only good things." Can you try at all? Or Gale who makes no attempt to come as someone you would even want in your party? Astarion didn't even join me until I needed a fourth member. Look at Ifan from Divinity Orginal Sin 2, he's immediately interesting. When you meet on the boat he's personable but still kinda mean, you can see there's more beneath the surface instantly. He's always meeting mysterious people doing very hush hush things, you want to know what the big secret is. I don't care about any of the companions or their secrets in BG3. Why should I? I can't interact with them like they interact with me, and most of them are really annoying anyway. I didn't meet a single character during my gameplay that I thought "Oh wow, you're really cool, whether you're a companion or not I like your voice acting, story, and design so much that you're gonna be one of my favorite characters." It just isn't there, it's like they made caricatures based off D&D and some MCU Collab Clorox they found in a shed. Every single dialogue is awkward because of the silent protagonist. Why are people just talking at me, and I'm just reacting? I can't give a little "uh-huh" whenever I nod or something? Combined with the seven different dialogue choices that all do nothing except progress the dialogue, why should I care about the dialogue at all? Yeah the voice acting is cool, but if I know they'll just say the same thing anyway, I'll just pick number one, read, and skip. It's like Larian looked at all the bad rpg dialogue trees and said "Ok, so if we give them seven dialogue choices instead of five or three, then the illusion of choice will actually matter to the player." No it doesn't. I ordered RPG with my CRPG, like it comes with the order. I shouldn't have to sit here and beg on my hands and knees to play a different game than other people are playing. "Oh I've replayed Act 1 so many times, it's so reactive." Literally how, show me the reactivity. I played for almost 11 hours and the world didn't acknowledge my existence at all, and it was made all the more obvious by the fact that everyone else was acknowledged because they had a voice! It's all fake, you know what a fugazi is? I hate this illusion of choice bs, it's the quickest way to turn me off a game. Also notice how nobody cared that I picked a Tiefling in the first quest? Here I am thinking "Maybe the Tieflings will be different to me because I'm a Tiefling, and I can cast Tiefling specific spells and help them more than I would in say, a dark elf playthrough." Lmao, why would I think there would be RPG elements in this game? Here's a couple random dialogue choices, they won't do anything different but maybe the character will mention tieflings in that response, then carry on with their original monologue. And they are monologues btw, I keep referring to them as dialogues but my party members were extremely silent the whole time. And your character just stares. Everyone else is having a grand old time but me? I'm just there to react. Grandpa died? Sad face. Grandpa came back from the dead? Happy face. Tell me more in great detail about how your grandpa came back to life, I'd love to sit and react to your story while I click different buttons to make you say things. Can we talk about the build variety I've been dying to talk about the build variety. What build variety? You get spellllllls, god I love spells. There's a scroll for this and a scroll for that, a spell for this and a spell for that. And you WILL be using the same party composition as everyone else is, because Astarion HAS to be a vampire rogue, and Lae'zel HAS to be a melee swordfighter. Which means your main character HAS to be viable or it throws the balance off, which means you get NO build variety. "Oh boy I levelled up, what do I get?" A stat increase, now clap. Maybe you got a spell or two. What am I even supposed to do with that, why should I care that my party members are levelling when they just get "more powerful +1". Oh and Act 3 is still unfinished apparently? Why didn't they patch it later, or was it all that motion capture that was getting in the way? The reality is whenever Larian got a license from Wizards of the Coast it was going to be terrible from the start. Of course WoTC is going to make them charge $60 constantly because it's Wizards of The Coast. Of course the ingame mod loader will disable achievements but downloading them from Nexus won't, it's WoTC and they're anti-competitive, and of course you will have Larian defenders blindly parrot "every other game does it with mods." Of course the game would be as dumbed down as possible, it's WoTC, they need to make it "palatable for modern audinces". Speaking of which, really crazy how they went with 5e and not 3.5e right? Such a little coinky-dink. Of course they have to make their money back for their really expensive motion capture and voice acting work. And, of course, there will be people that shut off their brain, plug their ears, and say "lah lah lah, I can't hear you." because they don't want to admit they didn't know what a CRPG even was before this took home every game of the year award in an objectively really mid year for video games. If you care about voice acting, and motion capture, and beautiful graphics, and shallow hot characters, that's fine! But be honest about it, don't go touting your game around as God's gift to the earth because it has all those things. The constant $60 implies quality, and in those things I can find quality in. But I wanted a CRPG, not a motion capture simulator. This is the only review I have comments on, I'm not a hater by any means. In fact I have a lot of respect for Baldur's Gate, they were generational games that went on to inspire a lot of my favorite franchise. But this game is mediocre, and it sacrificed all the role-playing to focus more on voice acting and motion capture. If anyone wants to debate that with me here, that's fine. Again though, stop acting like your game is made out of solid gold, because it very much isn't.

After two failed attempts, I finally completed the game on my third try and it was absolutely worth it. Baldur’s Gate III is one of those titles that captivates you with its scale, writing, and sheer freedom of choice, making every session feel like a brand-new story. Each area is an adventure of its own. While there is a clear main mission, the real charm appears through exploration: side quests unfolding naturally, unexpected events triggering out of nowhere, and unique encounters that only happen because you chose a different path or interacted with the right (or wrong) character. The world reacts to the player in a way that feels alive, unpredictable, and genuinely responsive. The game’s decision-and-consequence system is at its absolute best here. There’s no “right” or “wrong” choice only different paths that meaningfully reshape the narrative, the world, and even your companions. Speaking of them, the game offers multiple recruitable companions, each with a rich backstory, personal struggles, and motivations. Building your party becomes not just a matter of strategy, but emotional connection. Another highlight is the incredible freedom in character creation. You can fully create your own character, customizing appearance, class, origin, and the moral path you want to follow. Want to be a noble hero? A manipulative schemer? A chaotic wildcard? Everything is possible and the world adapts accordingly. The game also allows romantic relationships, with one companion or several, depending on your choices. Larian didn’t hold back in exploring these dynamics, giving surprising depth to the bonds you can form. What’s truly impressive is that Baldur’s Gate III is clearly designed to be replayed multiple times. Every new campaign feels unique whether due to a new class, different decisions, or simply interacting with characters in fresh ways. In summary: Baldur’s Gate III is one of the most complete, rich, and rewarding RPGs of the last decade. It’s a game that celebrates curiosity, creativity, and bold choices. Anyone who dives into this world will walk away feeling like they’ve lived a personal epic.

I'll be straightforward: Baldur's Gate 3 is, in my opinion, the best game of the last decade. Of course, it’s not for everyone — at times it can feel overwhelming and slow, which may be a huge turn-off for some players. That said, the production value is absolutely insane. From the very start you’re given meaningful choices: a wide variety of races, classes, and origins. The story follows a general pattern, but it offers so many decisions and branches that every playthrough feels unique. Most games never even attempt this level of complexity because of the production costs. The gameplay is incredibly rewarding and demands a strategic approach — party composition, skill selection, and even when to rest at camp all matter. Dialogues are superb: there are many moments when you’re surrounded by enemies and can talk your way out instead of fighting. And when the fight does begin, it’s often challenging, which makes dialogue itself feel like a core part of the gameplay. Add to that the well-written companions and an engaging story overall, and you have Baldur’s Gate 3 — an absolute masterpiece. Honestly, I’ve been waiting for something like this since Dragon Age: Origins.

An absolutely incredible game and experience. Overall, if it wasn't for Larian themselves, I would likely give this game a 9/10, but just due to the sheer care put into the game as well as the consumer friendly decisions (no microtransactions, no DRM), they deserve the 10/10. As far as the game itself, it is a truly remarkable experience. I just finally beat the game after 141 hours played. Overall, it was just incredible. I have never played a D&D game because I always felt they would pale in comparison. This game reminded me how fun it is to play a character. I spent over 2 hours in character creation alone. From the absolutely incredible (perhaps some of the best even) voice acting I have ever heard, an environment that keeps you guessing what's next, and turn-based combat that had me on my toes trying to figure out what to do next at times, this game truly delivers in every way. I loved how it looked, I loved how it played, I loved the story it delivered. To me, the tale **** RPG is one where you are considering your next character by the end of the first play through. I was considering my next character by the end of the first Act. There are some issues, to be clear. Act 3 can be quite buggy. i came across several bugs that at times I would need to reload earlier saves to resolve. But bugs can always be ironed out. A game needs a good core concept or it can never be fixed, and this game has it in droves. The only real criticism of the game itself is that I did feel as though the ending was missing just a bit more, though not nearly as much as some feel. I just feel like the end could have been slightly more fleshed out at certain points. Still, this did not hinder my enjoyment by much at all. I'll say this. There is a singular point in the game where you are fighting this individual who you've been having a mental dance with for some time. During this fight, the music because a duet between this person and someone else, and this person literally sings in the song, as you fight them. It is such an incredible and fun and just... unique moment. I cannot recommend this game enough. TL;DR - An incredibly beautiful game with dense storytelling, incredible amounts of player choice, combat that will test your mettle (or not if you just choose easier difficulty), and some of the best music and voice acting I have ever heard. If you are interested in a game that has more cutscenes that any game you have ever played and have an interest in turn-based combat, you should absolutely try this game.

I have nothing to contribute that has not already been said by thousands of other people. It's a great successor to the first two Baldur's Gate games, and and one of the best CRPG's I've ever played. The options for dialogue and choice are plentiful, giving about as much control over the story as you can hope for, and while there are some events where there is a clear evil path vs good path, there is still plenty of gray area that you can fall into without feeling railroaded like many other series. I will say that there isn't a lot of hand-holding, so for people who aren't familiar with D&D and/or Larian game mechanics, the learning curve can be really steep (though I did find the gameplay to be more intuitive than Divinity II: Original Sin). It's also extremely dense, particularly in Act 3; I'm about 120 hours in and I still have numerous quests left to complete before the endgame. Overall, I would say this is one of the best computer games to capture the experience of playing a TTRPG campaign, and while not perfect, it definitely deserves all of the accolades it has received.

If I could give "mixed" opinion, I would. I give it bad rating because it's overhyped. I'll probably get clowned but w/e Good: I mostly enjoyed combat, a lot of mechanics, build varieties etc., A lot of content The game is very creative, in story, characters and exploration It sucked me in during Act 1 and 2 Bad: -The biggest thing - ultimately I didn't care for the story or my companions. Something just didn't resonate with me. Party members range from mega cringe ones that I hated to tolerable, but I wouldn't want to hang out with any of them. I felt the same as when watching a modern show on Netflix. -The Mindflayers are overused in DnD, I almost hate the Gith'yanki, and those two are main pillars of the story. -After Act 1 there's a huge drop in quality and freedom, Act 2 is much more streamlined and Act 3 is just much worse. -Story and writing is often so cringe, it's hard to bear. People praise this game for writing, but no, it's not good. -I played BG1 and BG2 a lot and and was hoping for similar vibes here, but unfortunately it's different. It's a bigger problem with which direction the whole DnD went in (and the Modern sensibilities). -A lot of bugs, I started to play long time after release and finished on patch 7, and still the game had a lot of annoying bugs. -While combat mechanics are good and I appreciate the amazing possibilities they give, the balance was often bad. It's more of a DnD problem, but basically all combat is decided in the first round. You land that Stun on key enemy, you win, they land it on you - time to reload. End game combat is even worse when enemies to 40-50 damage per attack. So it's not much a long, tactical combat, it's just - position well, surprise them, hope for 2-3 main effects to land. -I felt like this game took way too long. I was wasting time on things that should be more smooth, everything is sooo sloow. It should've taken 40% of the time it took me to finish. -The UI, specifically inventory management. Oh my god, just frustrating. Camera is broken, targeting often doesn't work. Overall is it a good game? Sure Is it worth +100 hours? Not sure Is it game of the decade, or best game ever? No Does it have best characters/history ever? No

⁹ Baldur's Gate 3 es una joya moderna que captura la esencia y la grandeza de los juegos de rol clásicos mientras introduce nuevas y emocionantes mecánicas. Desarrollado por Larian Studios, este título en acceso anticipado lleva la icónica serie a nuevas alturas, ofreciendo una experiencia de juego inmersiva y cautivadora que seguramente atraerá a cualquier amante de los juegos de rol. 1. **Narrativa Profunda y Elecciones Significativas**: Al igual que sus predecesores, Baldur's Gate 3 se basa en una narrativa rica y envolvente. Tu personaje, un "peregrino" infectado por una entidad misteriosa, se embarcará en una búsqueda épica para descubrir la verdad detrás de los acontecimientos que sacuden la región. Las elecciones que tomes en el camino no solo afectarán la historia, sino también cómo los personajes te perciben y cómo evoluciona tu propio personaje. 2. **Mundo Abierto y Detallado**: El juego te sumerge en el mundo de Dungeons & Dragons, lleno de misterios, criaturas y lugares fascinantes por explorar. Cada rincón del mundo está repleto de detalles y posibilidades. Desde las ciudades bulliciosas hasta los espeluznantes pantanos, la variedad de entornos enriquece la inmersión en el juego. 3. **Interacciones y Compañeros Memorables**: La selección de personajes compañeros en Baldur's Gate 3 es diversa y repleta de personalidad. Cada uno de ellos tiene una historia y un trasfondo únicos, y tus interacciones con ellos pueden desencadenar eventos fascinantes. La forma en que te relacionas con tus compañeros y otros personajes puede influir en el desarrollo de la historia y en las reacciones futuras. 4. **Sistema de Combate Táctico y Dinámico**: El sistema de combate de Baldur's Gate 3 combina elementos por turnos con mecánicas en tiempo real. Esto crea una experiencia táctica donde debes planificar y ejecutar estrategias en el fragor de la batalla. Los hechizos, las habilidades y la interacción con el entorno brindan profundidad y emoción a los combates. 5. **Gráficos Detallados y Atmosféricos**: Los visuales de Baldur's Gate 3 son impresionantes. Los entornos, los personajes y las criaturas están ricamente detallados, lo que crea una experiencia visualmente cautivadora. Los efectos de iluminación y las expresiones faciales realistas también contribuyen a la inmersión en el mundo del juego. 6. **Acceso Anticipado y Mejoras Continuas**: A pesar de estar en acceso anticipado, Baldur's Gate 3 ya ofrece una experiencia sólida y emocionante. Además, Larian Studios está comprometido a mejorar y expandir el juego en función de los comentarios de la comunidad. Esto significa que, a medida que el juego evoluciona, puedes esperar aún más contenido y mejoras. En resumen, Baldur's Gate 3 es una oferta tentadora para todos los amantes de los juegos de rol y las aventuras épicas. Su narrativa profunda, su mundo detallado, sus personajes memorables y su sistema de combate desafiante se combinan para brindar una experiencia de juego de rol moderna pero fiel a las raíces de la serie. Si estás buscando una experiencia inmersiva y emocionante que te permita dar forma a tu propia historia, Baldur's Gate 3 es un juego que seguramente te cautivará y te mantendrá regresando por más.

The game is ok but far from being a good game, except the graphism, there are a ton of issue, but i'll explain in french: - Jeu truffé de bugs même après de nombreux patch (j'ai connu moins de bugs en jouant au dernier jeu pokémon...), mais bizarrement accepté comme étant une norme pour les joueurs PC... - Temps de chargement EXTREMEMENT long même avec un bon PC. - Un tutoriel très mal foutu, quasi absent, j'ai appris l'usage de la touche "Alt" uniquement grâce à des vidéos après 50h de jeu, par exemple ! - Les romances claquées au sol, on peut passer tout notre temps avec tel ou tel compagnon, avec une affinité excellente mais il ne se passera rien avec, et pourtant des personnages avec qui on aura quasiment eu aucune interaction vont nous forcer à coucher avec... car oui, soit on a une proposition pour les recaler très violemment, soit toutes les autres seraient même lorsque cela n'est pas dit explicitement des invitations à baiser. - On remarque que le second degré et l'ironie est totalement absent du jeu, càd qu'il faut prendre au pied et à la lettre tout ce qui est dit, ça tue l'immersion dans un RPG ! - La gestion des items est catastrophique, les items mettent parfois du temps à apparaître, le tri automatique est malfoutu, et on ne comprend pas pourquoi ils ne sont pas automatiquement rangés dans les sacs de notre inventaire, on ne sait pas quels items ont de l'importance ou s'ils servent juste à la revente. - La gestion de la caméra est au moins aussi catastrophique, notamment lorsque les combats se font sur plusieurs étages... - Quant au scénario et lore, il est bon et organique, mais loin d'être extraordinaire pour ne pas dire convenu. En fait c'est du niveau d'une prod netflix, ça se suit. - Pas de VF, Zelda TOTK et Starfield en ont, qualité qu'avait un jeu tel que TW3 aussi... - C'est un reskin de DOS2 avec un gameplay simplifié + jet de dé (qui selon moi n'est pas toujours pertinent). - Ll'exploration est très mal récompensée, surtout quand il s'agit de looter 150 pièces d'or et un vieux parchemin... une manière artificielle d'allonger la durée de vie du jeu en mettant plein de vases/caisses que l'on va vérifier dans l'espoir de trouver un objet un minimum précieux.

As someone who doesn't have a group of friends with the desire and/or, more likely, the time commitment necessary to start a real D&D campaign with, I find game is a fantastic way of getting more familiar with the breadth and depth of what it can offer. While there are some parts to BG3 that are a one-to-one match with it's D&D counterpart, there are others that are completely different. Regardless, it's an amazingly fun experience. Truthfully, many of my initial hours playing it was solo and, inevitably, I would find myself overwhelmed by not only having to build and play my character (whatever class they may be), but then having to understand building and playing each of my party members as well. This resulted in me stalling out on my first couple characters before even completing Act 1. Now I'm enjoying playing co-op with a friend, which allows me to learn how they are making decisions for the extra character they manage and can give me advice on how to handle and play the extra character I manage. That is helping me gain the confidence I need to actually entertain playing through the game solo after our co-op run is complete. I expect to be playing this game for many years to come.

Baldur’s Gate 3 is nothing short of a masterpiece—a Dungeons & Dragons dream come to life with breathtaking storytelling, deep role-playing mechanics, and endless player freedom. It is without a doubt that the game in question will receive the title of "Game of the Year". The level of detail present in the game is truly remarkable, ranging from the intricacies of the musical score to the staggering 174 hours of cinematic content. Furthermore, the combat system is a flawless adaptation of the original Dungeons and Dragons game. It is perplexing to encounter negative reviews of this game, particularly those from individuals who lack a fundamental understanding of turn-based RPGs. Criticisms regarding the length of combat and the abundance of cutscenes are unfounded and demonstrate a lack of comprehension. It is inappropriate for such individuals to provide reviews if they are unable to grasp the fundamental concepts of the game. It is suggested that they instead play games such as Call of Duty.

Baldur’s Gate 3 is nothing short of a masterpiece. Larian Studios has crafted an RPG that not only pays homage to its legendary predecessors but also raises the bar for storytelling, gameplay, and player choice in the genre. From the moment you create your character, you’re drawn into a rich, immersive world where every decision matters. The character customization is deep and flexible, allowing you to create exactly the hero—or anti-hero—you envision. The turn-based combat is a thrilling blend of strategy and creativity, staying true to Dungeons & Dragons 5th Edition rules while remaining accessible to newcomers. The writing and voice acting are phenomenal. Every companion is memorable, with unique backstories, quirks, and motivations that make them feel alive. The moral dilemmas and branching storylines ensure no two playthroughs are alike, encouraging you to explore every corner of the game. Graphically, the game is stunning. The attention to detail in the environments, character models, and animations makes every moment a visual treat. The soundtrack is equally impressive, perfectly capturing the epic and emotional beats of the story. Baldur’s Gate 3 isn’t just a game; it’s an experience. Whether you’re a long-time fan of the series or a newcomer to the franchise, this is a must-play title that sets a new standard for RPGs. Highly recommended!

Absolutely amazing game which is a worthy continuation of legendary BG1 and BG2 which i loved and play as a young teenager. I just finished my first playthrough and I have enjoyed it all the way through. Game is huge. I have tried to visit every corner and finish every quest and it took me 220 hours to do it. But it never gets boring. Main story is amazing and you are really making it your own based on decisions you take during playthrough. Sidequests are entertaining and engaging. There was not a moment when I felt like doing chores. I have two things which I would prefer differently though...: 1. Lack of party members and small party - only 4 party members give you very little space for experimenting and varying your set up. 2. Max level is only level 12 which doesn't give you access to most powerful and interresting spells and skills. Also, as a veteran of genre, which I probably am as I played many D&D type games, I made a mistake of picking balanced difficulty. Well, it was really easy. Only one "hard" fight in game was Raphael, but still fell on first try. And for example dragon Ansur didn't even get a turn. Strategical element of game was kind of non-existent due to it being so easy. And things like buffing are totally useless on balanced difficulty. Also kind of non-existent in game. Concentration during most of buffing spells I didn't really like neither, but ok, it is what it is. But none of my complaints are game breaking or preventing people from fully enoying beautiful and engaging story. It really does not have competition in this genre regarding quality of visuals and voice acting. Also, lower difficulty and simplified rules are great for people with no experience in genre. It is really easy to get into playing BG3 even if you have no clue what D&D is about. I see here some negative reviews regarding story or lack of tutorial - even probably written by same person under different accounts. Well, it is absolute BS. If someone says that story is missing, then it is absolute delusional idiot. And if you can't figure out how to play this in like 1 hour tops, then stay away from any game which requires at least slight use of brain forever. King of the genre stays for me convincingly Pathfinder: WoTR. And in terms of game mechanics I also prefer other games, like for example Pillars of Eternity, Neverwinter nights or even Divinity Original Sin. But in terms of perfect storytelling, Baldur's Gate 3 has no equal and it is absolutely worth playing. I will play definitely again, although I will pump my difficullty up.

First, forget the hype. Like most hyped games, that view is pretty distorted. The basic game is pretty good if you like turn based RPG's. Cons: This will depend on your point of view, but everyone... and I do mean everyone... will try to seduce you. I'd like a toggle to reserve this behavior from a specific gender. So far, I have seen no mods to help with this. The unmodded classes and mechanics can be very unwieldy. The necormancer for instance needs corpses to make undead, and they all vanish whenever you take a long rest. That is horribly frustrating. Mods: These are both good and bad. Mods can save the day for this game, fixing the akwardness of the base classes and mechanics while adding new interesting ones. It turns an ok/pretty good game into a great one. BUT... this will also make the game more unstable. Crashes are a problem even with the base game, and mods make it worse.

“In a world teetering on the brink of oblivion, you made a choice… to play Baldur’s Gate 3. And what a choice it was.” A tale woven from dice rolls, desire, and dire consequences. Your journey began with a parasite in your skull and a thousand possibilities in your hands. You met unlikely companions—broken, dangerous, beautiful—and together, you shaped fate itself. You charmed devils, battled gods, and romanced vampires. You saved lives… or extinguished them. You faced your past, rewrote your future, and carved a path through a world that responded to your every move. Combat was not merely battle—it was a dance. A turn-based symphony of blades, spells, and tactical brilliance. And every dialogue was a roll of the dice—every word, a chance to change the world. You didn’t just play a game. You lived a story. And it remembered you. This… is .

This may very well be the best game of all time. It is, most definitely, the best game that I've ever played. Incredible character customization, incredible voice acting, and incredible execution and alteration of D&D 5th edition. This game is INCREDIBLY well executed in nearly everything it does. There is an incredible amount of content, to the degree that you'll likely never even see it all. I cannot, I repeat, CANNOT do this game justice in just this review. If you love unique and well-written characters-- and perhaps romancing those characters, this game is for you. If you love well-executed turn-based combat that nearly perfectly emulates-- and in some ways exceeds-- D&D 5th edition, then this game is for you. If you love spending an hour customizing your character with an expansive list of options and different looks, then this game is for you. And, if after all that you're still not completely satisfied-- the Devs made an in-game MOD MANAGER where the community can post all of their glorious mods to tweak and add to the game's experience. As a result, this game's replay-ability is effectively limitless. BUY THIS GAME. Also this game's soundtrack is beautiful and ethereal, give it a full listen at some point-- it deserves it.

I was reticent to buy or play BG3 for myself, having already seen the main story play through on some let's plays. Thing is, I really wanted to avoid the whole romancing thing, unless the option to be a Matchmaker was an option: let's see how an Astarion / Shadowheart relationship work or Halsin and Gale, dialogue options and stuff, you know? But then the stars aligned: I got a new computer, I had some savings, and the game went on sale. Screw it, let's actually play. Now I can't stop playing. Already over 200 hours in just 2 months. I keep thinking of new build options, good/evil paths to take, NPC interactions I might have missed, loot to toy with. A Landmark RPG That Raises the Bar – Deep, Beautiful, and Wildly Replayable Baldur’s Gate 3 is one of the most immersive and emotionally resonant RPGs I’ve ever played. From the opening moments, it wraps you in storytelling that feels personal, layered, and alive. Every character has depth. Every choice you make has weight. You’re not just playing a game—you’re living a story. The pros are too many to list, but here’s a taste: Incredible writing: Sharp, funny, heartbreaking, and clever—sometimes all at once. Whether you're new to D&D or a veteran, it respects your intelligence and rewards your curiosity. Companions: Some of the best-written and most compelling companions in any RPG. Each has a rich backstory, evolving relationships, and paths that react to your decisions. Tactical gameplay: The turn-based combat is deep but never overwhelming. Creative problem-solving is encouraged—you can charm enemies, shove them off ledges, or set the battlefield on fire. Custom characters: From race and class to personal background and dialogue style, you can shape your character’s identity and morality however you want. Immersive world: The environments are absolutely gorgeous and bursting with secrets. It feels like a living, breathing world. Replayability: Your choices drastically change how the game unfolds, and no two playthroughs are the same. Mod support: There’s already a thriving modding scene, and Larian has supported it well, letting players tweak visuals, balance, and even add features. There are a few rough spots: The length of the game, while a dream for many RPG fans, might be daunting for those looking for a shorter or more casual experience. Accessibility is a real issue. Visually impaired players have very limited support—there’s no text-to-speech for non-dialogue elements, and you actually need a mod to move the minimap. Other accessibility options, like scalable UI, better contrast, or auditory cues, are sorely missing. Still, for everything it offers—emotion, choice, creativity, spectacle, and sheer roleplaying freedom—Baldur’s Gate 3 stands tall as one of the most ambitious and lovingly crafted games in years. The care Larian poured into every scene is obvious, and it’s a triumph of storytelling and design that raises the bar for RPGs going forward.

In a month, I've managed to finish three full playthroughs of Baldur's Gate 3. This is now my favourite RPG of all time. It truly elevates the genre to new heights. Presentation is top-notch, with excellent voice acting across the board, beautifully motion-captured scenes, and wonderful music. In fact, there's one late-game boss that has my favourite boss theme of all time, which fits not only the character but the events leading up to it absolutely perfectly (if you know, you know). Every single member of the cast knocks it out of the park with their performances - even the minor NPCs with one line of dialogue. It's a joy to interact with them all. And the story is outstanding. There are so many minor interactions and special dialogue lines based on everything from the situation to your race to who's in your party to your class to even your subclass - I played a Draconic Bloodline Sorcerer on my second playthrough and noticed dialogue related to my character's draconic ancestry. It's that complex! Combat is quite fast-paced for a turn-based game, and every hit, every spell effect, and every kill is super satisfying. It helps if you enjoy turn-based combat to begin with, but this is some of gaming's best. There's so many little interactions with the environment, like being able to shoot braziers down, push statues over, shove enemies into chasms (a personal favourite), and so on. You can even throw enemies at other enemies! Combat is always exciting and a lot of the encounters are very creative. The overall story is just phenomenal. No spoilers, but I found the best way to play is to really get into your character's shoes and properly role-play as them. The bad dice rolls really gave my first character (a bard) that extra level of incompetence as he tried to bungle his way through every encounter. The good dice rolls made my second character (a sorcerer) feel that little bit more intimidating and powerful. I'm not saying it's wrong to "save scum" (i.e; reload a save when you get a bad result on a skill check), but it was so much more fun for me to live with my mistakes. All of your companion characters are extremely well-written and all have great moments, ranging from hilarious to tragic. Romance is... abundant. The game's a bit too horny sometimes! But seriously, committing to one character and watching your romance blossom alongside their own personal story is a wonderful experience. Questing is excellent. There's so many outcomes, and so many variations of consequences, that no two playthroughs will ever be the same. And that's not hyberbole - as I said, I've done three playthroughs, and they've all been wildly different. The main story eventually leads to the same conclusion, but even that has a bunch of different choices and outcomes. There's a "big choice" at the end but all of the events leading up to it have an impact. It's not like Mass Effect 3's RGB ending by any stretch of the imagination. I'm going to echo a lot of player sentiment here, but Baldur's Gate 3 is what I wanted a Dragon Age: Origins sequel to be, in every way. It does everything that game did and then some, bringing that peak Bioware style to the modern age. Hats off to Larian for finally delivering what Bioware unfortunately couldn't. This is easily one of the greatest games ever made, and I hope it inspires more excellent RPGs in the future.

Masterpiece, a new reference in the genre and really unique. If you haven't played party based RPGS or DND and would like to get a sample try this one, it's a blast to play. Story-wise the game is brilliant. You progress story through the main quests but really fill the gaps and expand through sides and exploration. The world is telling you a story of its own, and it's so cool to go out there and discover it. Decisions matter, and they will greatly influence your playthrough. Origin characters are really charismatic and interesting to play with, I loved having them around. The same can be said for lots of the secondary characters. The VAs are amazing, they really live the characters.Graphics and settings/levels are amazing, it is so immersive. The music and sounds are really good too, I hope they had added more voiced tracks like the one in the "House of Hope".Building your own custom character while being able to respec easily at any moment is a joy. I really like the mechanics, rests/ spells / equipment etc. It was really cool to build my party over time, unlock abilities, use new equipment and strategies, mastering the party gameplay over time. You build your own strategy and feel it like your own, as well as how you carve your path. Agency feeling is high on this one.I like how chaotic, complex and unpredictable the game can be. If you've played outer wilds, this one also has that feeling of accompiishment when you discover how something works, or how to smartly play an encounter. For the curious and picky, it's wonderful. You will be rewarded for going the extra **** the final mission, I dislike how ally help is implemented. You need to call on them per fight, and waste an action doing so. It is quite discouraging to the point I barely used it. I would have strongly preferred allies to show up along the way as you progress through it if you have that ally available.Inventory management is a bit of a mess, and there are many things that shouldn't be there. Why do I want food in my inventory? It's useless, I just want it to go to camp for me to be able to long rest effectively. Also, I'd like to have more distinctive bags to put stuff in (Scroll bag, weapons bag...). I missed some important mechanics due to the game not telling you about them, like the possibility of going to camp mostly at any time or the idea of sending all food to camp since it is only useless there and it weighs quite a lot making you encumbered often (PS: Karlach is a good mule). I dislike how the game makes you feel a bit too much urgency at first, thorugh cinematics that are kinda encouraging you to take haste even though you can rest as many times as needed. It made my first act more difficult as I was trying not to waste spells. You may skip some cutscenes because you didn't long rest at that precise location too.A tip, don't hesitate to use scrolls, potions, elixirs and such. I had the typical need of hoarding them to be used "in the future" and ended up by not using most. Make use of the resources at **** game leaves me with a feeling of mastery of my particular party, but with an urge to try out other combinations and learn about different paths and strategies. Also, can't wait for Steam Workshop support. This game will greatly benefit from modding. Act 3 still has some bugs that need to be addressed and some things were left unfinished (infernal iron?).Looking forward to play this coop at some point, if you are looking for an adventure look no further.
