Great classic RPG. That said, it might not be for everyone. Here are some tidbits that might affect your enjoyment, depending on your tastes and priorities: * Heavy emphasis on RNG: RNG decides a lot of outcomes in this game and can be really frustrating at times. * Turn-based combat: Yeah, it's slow, especially when fighting large groups of enemies. * Movement is very slow: Your group moves rather slowly and you can find yourself looking at your party move somewhere for minutes on end. * You will be reloading A-LOT: The RNG, combined with the limited healing options really forces you to reload frequently. * Plot is very "Sci-Fi Fantasy": While D&D is known for its slightly cheesy world, this game leans very heavily into the "Dark Fantasy & Sci-Fi" elements of D&D. * Combat can be challenging, but also offers a lot of room for exploits. Given the game's many rules, spells, mechanics and items there are hundreds of ways to cheese and exploit fights if you want to. * Act3 is more disjointed and less polished than Act1 and 2. While the first two Acts offer a clear main objective, Act3's more "free form" outcomes are less satisfying as not everything gets a fair conclusion.

Tl/DR: BG3 is a difficult and time consuming slog-fest. I like some of the characters and the role-playing aspects, but otherwise find the whole thing to be a frustrating experience. I'm past the 50 hour mark and still in "Act 1" so maybe things get better, but there's been too many moments in this game that have made for an infuriating experience. Ultimately, I think BG 3 is too difficult for me and I can't figure out what the game wants me to do instead. I have to go online looking up what to do for the majority of the quests and constant roadblocks as it's not intuitive and NONE of it is explained to the player. Getting stuck is a constant. Other players give their ideas about how to cheese the very difficult fights like "oh, you need to round up explosive barrels and place them where the dude is sitting", but cheese shouldn't be required to get through the fight. That's poor design. I keep leveling up, getting new weapons, armor, and abilities, but I don't feel like my characters ever truly get stronger. I get pummeled in these fights and when I do win, it's because I was chugging potions the entire time and barely scraping by. The whole game is a slog. It takes a long time to complete a battle (that you might not win and then have to start over) or to loot a room and - like many modern games these days - you're constantly managing a HUGE inventory. It's oddly difficult getting party members outside of your immediate party equipped unless you go back to camp and swap people around. Again, it just slows things down and makes the game feel like a slog. Did you cast a few spells? Cool, now you need to go back to camp. Again. Did you long rest? Ok, now you need to make your way over to the one merchant in the game to see if you can have a few more potions or camp supplies (what happens if you run out of supplies? Are you just soft-locked at that point? I wouldn't put it past this game). I'll lower the difficulty and keep playing because I do enjoy the role playing aspects and some of the less eccentric characters. But I had high hopes for this game due to the glowing reviews and so far have been mostly let down by it. BG 3 is pretty mid at best. Notable moments so far: --Not being able to stealth on a rogue without the enemy immediately seeing you. So what's the point then? --Pulling the entire goblin camp several times over and needing to reload again and again. --Pulling the entire forge camp or whoever those guys are in the underdark forge. --Several other fights in the game where it is 10+ enemies versus your party and I'm at the mercy of how many potions I happen to have left. --Being literally unable to reach or attack an enemy on a high level of the map as he continued to rain down death upon us --Trying to use a forge that took forever to reach only to be attacked by a 300hp level 10 guardian who 1-shot the entire party. --Miss. Miss. Miss. Miss. Miss. Miss. Ooo I hit them the enemy for 4 damage! Miss. Miss. Miss. Miss. --Fights being completely reliant on RNG mechanics so it doesn't matter how many times you level up or what you have equipped. Enemies can and will still stomp you. --Choosing heavy armor for my barbarian because why not, heavy armor sounds cool, only to find out that wearing heavy armor hurts my rage and barbarians don't actually wear heavy armor. Then why give me the option to specialize in it? Why can't I filter out things that are obviously not intended for my character/class?

Esse foi o meu primeiro jogo do gênero e eu não sabia exatamente se eu ia gostar. Existem inúmeras soluções para qualquer tipo de problema que você encontre, seja ele em combate ou não. Você decide o que você faz no jogo e como, e eu também gosto que o jogo te dá recompensas muito boas só porque você resolveu falar com um aleatório no meio do caminho sem saber se isso ia dar em briga ou em uma boa história. Tem tanta coisa nesse jogo, mas eu queria falar sobre o trabalho dos dubladores. Eu acho que todo mundo tem seu talento, mas as histórias do Astarion e a da Karlach foram as que me passaram a maior emoção. E com algumas repetições de saves pra escolher coisas diferentes por curiosidade, você pode ver que qualquer escolha que você faz com qualquer companion traz uma atuação INCRÍVEL de qualquer forma. Tudo nesse jogo é incrível pra falar a verdade. Os lugares, as pessoas, as missões, as histórias, as oportunidades. Como eu escrevi em outro lugar, Baldur's Gate 3 pra mim foi uma mesa cheia de pó branco e eu fui o Tony Montana. E acho que vou ser por mais umas 300hrs no mínimo.

Baldur’s Gate 3 - A Masterpiece BG3 is a true role-playing game in every sense. Every decision—whether in dialogue, combat, or exploration—has meaningful consequences. Want to betray your allies, side with the villains, or find a morally gray third option? The game lets you do it (Although half the times my morals don't). The sheer number of branching stories is staggering, making each playthrough feel unique and completely different. The turn-based combat, based on Dungeons & Dragons 5e, is extremely deep, complex and rewarding. Positioning, environmental effects (like setting oil on fire, throwing team mates/Gnomes/etc.), and creative spell usage make every encounter feel dynamic. Higher difficulties provide a real challenge, forcing you to think strategically (Sometimes can't just fight your way out of situations...) From the lush forests of the Emerald Grove to the eerie depths of the Underdark, BG3 is visually breathtaking. The facial animations and motion-capture performances set a new standard for immersion in ARPGs. The soundtrack, composed by Borislav Slavov, is absolutely beautiful. Larian has crafted something truly special here—BG3 isn’t just a game; it’s an adventure you’ll remember, with characters you'll hopelessly fall for (Scratch <3)

after being stuck in act 1 for almost two years, i finally finished baldur’s gate 3, and it’s hard not to respect how massive and ambitious this game is. act 2 was easily my favorite part and, honestly, pretty close to perfect. the tone, the pacing, the atmosphere, everything just clicked there in a way the rest of the game doesn’t always manage. most of the companions are really likeable, but karlach, wyll, and shadowheart were on another level for me and stayed in my party basically the entire time. karlach’s story especially hit hard. her arc and its conclusion are genuinely heartbreaking, and it’s easily the one i’ll remember the most. act 3 is where the game starts to lose its footing. the moment you arrive in the city, you can feel the dip in focus and overall quest quality. without spoiling anything, it leans hard into classic rpg nonsense. the game keeps telling you there’s an urgent, city-ending threat, but at the same time it’s perfectly happy letting you spend hours doing side quests like investigating who killed a circus clown. some of these quests are fun, but they completely kill the sense of urgency the story is trying to build. that said, the actual endgame and final stretch do a great job at pulling things back together and delivering a strong payoff. another issue i had is that choice density doesn’t always equal meaningful choice. late in the game you can unlock abilities that make dice rolls almost trivial, even really high ones like 25 or 30. this leads to some pretty weird situations where everyone just instantly believes you and everything goes your way, including outcomes that feel like the developers never really expected most players to reach. it’s cool at first, but it also removes a lot of tension and makes some story moments feel a bit hollow. flaws aside, baldur’s gate 3 is still an incredible achievement. it’s huge, deeply crafted, and full of memorable characters and moments. act 3 may stumble, but the journey as a whole, especially the ending, still makes it something really special.

I did enjoy this game very very much with my husband but I need to be clear. This game is very good especially in this era of gaming. The possibilities are soooo numerous! You can do so many things. If you can think it, there's a huge chance you can do it. Larian Studios has done a phenomenal job! However, it bothers me a great deal that people try to say that this game is better than the original Dragon Age Origins. it is not. DAO was an S tier game throughout the entire campaign. Baldur's Gate 3 falls short. BG3 has 3 parts before the final fight. The 1st part is amazing and the 2nd part is even better (best part of the game IMO). The 3rd part is where the game starts to slow down and just not live up to the gradual build the previous 2 parts had. It's strange because so much is going on due to you being in a major city but it is no where near as satisfying or important as the 1st two parts. It feels like the definition of quantity not quality. It doesn't have anywhere near the umph that the 2nd part has and don't even get me started on the final boss fight. That fight was just no where near as awesome as the final fight in DAO. I only compare the two because, in RPG circles, these two game are heavily compared. DAO is superior in my humble opinion, but please buy Baldur's Gate 3 because I really believe it will be one of the best in the 2020s. It is an amazing, wonderful game. Keep up the great work Larian Studios!

So I've just finished watching 40 minutes of credids (if you are the dude thanking themselve for being amazing there, let me push your ego a bit more. Yes, you are, beacuse you are part of the creation of an amazing game) and now I really want to write a review for this overwhelmingly awesome game. Just writing my thoughts down. I got this game recommended by a good friend. She promised me I would love it. So I got it on sale, downloaded it (steam told me it would take 14 Days to finish but someone cured my wifi over night so it was done the next day) and started it. Well let's say I was dissappointed. So much text to understand what my attacks are doing, irritated by the dice system and I hated the movement system. You point, you click, your character moves. I stopped playing the game after 30 hours cause of frustration. But after 3 months or so some other friends started playing the game and told me how awesome it is. So I got curious again, started a new playthrough, took the time for reading what my class is doing, what my spells are doing and what I can achieve with some weapons and armour. And then I started loving the game and it's mechanics. All companions are well written and you get a deep understanding of their intention and wishes over time. Nearly every dialog option you choose changes the game direction and sometimes you have to learn the prize of your chosen dialoge option the hard way. Because this game isn't just about fighting. It's also about talking to your companions (and every single NPC you can find) to get a feeling for the world you're living in. And every single conversation is voiced (Yes Every NPC hase a voiceover). That's so amazing! I really love it because that's a huge reason why you don't loose the motivation talking to some random NPC on the road that 's giving you an unexpected sidequest. Talking about Sidequests. They all feel somehow important. Some bring quite some interesting challenges. (Iron Throne being my favourite, if you know what I mean. If you have no idea, close your browser and stop searching. Don't get spoiled, it's amazing... and frustrating) So I would recommend doing as much sidequests as you can. If you are new to the game or think about buying it (it's woth it's price and I would definetly buy it if I were you) take some time and learn the game mechanics. You will read a lot. Even if it's annoying at the beginning, just do it. There are so many different ways to finish a battle if you know how your abilities work. Feel free to play in easy mode the first time you play. It's mostly more forgiving than other modes (I just have to guess here because I was too stubbern and played normal mode) but prepare for reloading the game many, many times. It's okay, don't feel bad about it. Just try again. I rarely had any bugs. Only some confused enemys climbing a wall 4 times a round or dashing in one direction just to misty step back at their original location. Oh and sometimes my cape was sticking in my torso. My character wasn't screaming in pain so I came to the conclousion that it's just a totally normal thing in this world. I would still not recommend trying to reproduce the Baldurians dresscode. Aaaand that's it. Congratulations for reading through all of this. I wish you an nice day/night/ -put every time of the day in here you want- and of cause a lot of fun playing this amazing game.

I went into Baldur's Gate 3 with little, if any, knowledge about games of the genre. TTRPGs or anything derived from them weren't ever as popular in my hometown as they were in the US or elsewhere, but I'd heard a lot of good things about this one in particular and wanted to see what it was about. Frankly, I wasn't disappointed. For starters, the amount of content in this game is, to put it lightly, absolutely insane. Every quest ties in with every other quest, there's continuity between acts (did I mention this has THREE ACTS of gameplay?) and a grand story where every character gets to realize themselves in unique ways. This was, at first, perhaps a bit overwhelming for a new player like me, but, slowly, I grew immersed and started to like the variety of things to do instead of aiming to complete everything in one run, like I hoped I would be able to. (Spoiler: it's impossible to do everything in one go. Who would've guessed?) Secondly, the amount of freedom at hand is baffling. Don't want to fight a boss on their terms? Find a spot where your entire party can pummel them until they die while they can do nothing. Wanna rob the local merchant of all his possessions? Sure, there's like 5 ways to do that. So long as there are spaces on the map to move to and actions you can perform or abilities you can cast, there is nothing stopping you from beating a section of the game in your own creative way. Last, but CERTAINLY not least, the characters. It feels like every living thing in the game has a unique personality, regardless if they're just a street vendor you find in a random spot in the city, or just some NPC in a populated area, or someone whose inclusion in the plot would completely change the outcome of the story. Few characters are actively boring, but, then again, interacting with most NPCs is optional anyway. BG3 is great, I could go on for a while. My only recommendation is to play with friends, seeing as my singleplayer playthrough would've definitely benefitted from that. Other than that, it's really not too hard for me to give this game a solid 10/10 (just wait for the next sale if the full price is too much for you)

- Visually stunning scenery, animations, and cutscenes - Top notch voice acting for every character, not just the main characters - Compelling, variable storyline for each companion / origin character - Immersive in-world lore that allows the game to be satisfyingly self contained while also fitting into the greater Dungeons and Dragons / Faerûn / 5th Edition world - Modified 5th Edition mechanics to streamline gameplay and provide certain quality of life improvements - Built in mod manager with thousands of free mods covering everything from expanded spells and abilities from other Dungeons and Dragons sources, mechanics changes for a more true-to-source experience, to purely visual updates for clothing, hairstyles, tattoos, and makeup - Extraordinarily high replay value; it's impossible to see the entire game in only a handful of playthroughs, and following a different character's arc delivers a fresh perspective that will influence decisions and major plot threads - Tons of Easter Eggs for those familiar with the earlier games in the series - Not suitable for children. While there are controls to disable nudity, the game themes and visuals are graphic and adult. Cutscenes and gameplay can include adult romance, sex, graphic murder and other violence, torture, slavery, abuse and trauma, suicide, theft, wanton destruction of property and environment, animal abuse, criminal organization, profanity, and many other themes that are disturbing to some individuals

I could probably write an entire essay about why I love the game, but I'll try to keep it short. The game shines with its huge, explorable world, its story with varied paths through seemingly endless conversation options, and a small element of chance: the dice roll. Depending on what you roll and which skills you've leveled, you can be lucky or unlucky in combat or in conversation options. An element you either love or hate (usually both). I also love the various companions you can add to your party through exploration throughout the story. With their distinct personalities and their stories, supported by top-notch voice actors, the characters feel truly real. Depending on your interactions, other characters can form a relationship with you or leave the party forever. No matter which path you ultimately choose, the game offers a journey you'll never forget. After two years, I'm already on my third save and I'm still seeing scenes I've never seen before. The new multiplayer and crossplay feature is also a lot of fun and a very nice addition. This game has deservedly become Game of the Year 2023, and I'm excited to see what other exciting projects Larian Studios will develop. All I can say is that the game is fantastic and will always hold a place in my heart.

The replayability is huge, and every decision actually feels meaningful. And the fights… oh my god, the fights. Deep, tactical, rewarding, and genuinely fun once you get the hang of **** took me one solid run to fully understand the mechanics and how everything works, but that’s what makes future runs even better. You start experimenting, taking risks, building differently, and it just keeps getting more satisfying. This game completely changed my perception of turn-based RPGs. Product received for free It could be a great game with more polish, in the late game all the negative aspects pile up and playing becomes unpleasant. + act I is well done + graphics + detailed world building with attention to details and even special voicelines for small things + a lot of content even though it's rushed/badly done in many places 1. Illusion of choice. The game presents itself as giving many choices but this is not true. Many decisions lead to the same result, many times the game decides for you. 2. Dice rolls are rigged. In certain moments to roll a 15 dice with proficiency and modifiers is harder than to roll a 25 in casual gameplay, even if you reroll with inspirations. For that reason you would want to quicksave and reload to achieve the desired result, thus making it actually YOUR choice. 3. If you don't play Drow you just lose game content because Drows get a special treatment 4. Utility/control spells are mostly useless. In 90% of cases only useful on large amounts of weak enemies and even then not guaranteed to work on most enemies. 5. This forces you to just always build into damage, it is simply easier and more efficient. You would rather do all actions into bursts of damage than waste them on anything else. In some moments you can only win if you have initiative, and if you wasted it on a failed CC spell you lose as the enemies quickly kill you. 6. There are only few useful classes (read as: damage classes), Shadowheart unironically works best as a sorcerer. As original class she misses most of her spells even in the late game. 7. In some areas you cannot go to long rest (which makes sense) but fights can be many and last for too long. If you waste important spells on first several fights then you approach the boss of the area naked with only melee damage and a few cantrips. Not good. The game forces you to save your resources and use your power carefully. But on your first playthrough you never know where to save and where to spend, so this results in you preserving valuable resources until the end of the game without the joy of using them. There is angelic slumber potion but it is rare and limited. 8. You can just buff your main character to oblivion and there is no incentive to utilize different characters in the game for different tasks. You can still do it but buffing your character is just simpler and easier. 9. Illithid powers suck, there is nothing about them that makes me want to contemplate taking them. I would consider them if they gave a free spell slot or allowed to cast fireballs for free. Only reactions are somewhat good, but even things like blast are too weak (barely 8 damage to a 100HP enemy when they cast a spell) 10. The game, not just characters but the game itself forces you to abandon your humanity in favor of said powers that suck. Even moreso, the game implies you have used these powers even if you didn't. 11. For some reason most male characters in the camp instantly want to jump onto you, you have to cringe and decline their "requests". - meanwhile Shadowheart takes a sh*tton of effort to even get kissed. Neither Minthara nor Karlach jump onto you right off the bat. But male characters do. And Lazael (literally a frog). Interesting. 12. Astarion: great acting, completely useless to the plot line and is a net negative to positive plays with his constant disagreeing and whining. The game wants to make you think that deep down he is a good person and he is only evil because he was tortured for hundreds of years or something. This is not how it works. Good people don't need convincing to be good no matters what horrible events happened to them. They may mistrust you, they may see everyone around as a threat, but if they are good, they remain good. Astarion is just an a*shole. 13. Bugs. Bugged gamepad UI. Voicelines get mixed together. Can't cast certain spells from a gamepad because subvariant selection wheel does not appear. Wyll talks to me like I have to save his father while his already saved father stands right next to him. Misleading quest markers. Spells like fog disappear after being cast. Many such things. - Especially bugged gamepad UI. Often you have to reopen the wheel 2 times for selection to work, telekinesis selection is bugged and broken, sometimes you have to reopen inventory a bunch of times for navigation to start working properly. Very annoying. 14. Baldurs Gate is presented as suffering from food shortage (this is important) and of course the guys who put themselves (native citizens) over refugees are painted in a bad light. I guess developers of this game did not learn about Leningrad blockade. When there is no food citizens start to eat each other. If you invite even more refugees to a city like this, refugees become the food. But the game pushes that suicidally empathic point of view on the player because developers apparently think that food manifests itself out of thin air, and said native citizens are just evil hoarders who do not want to share their abundance. 15. Long rest mechanic is cumbersome and deliberately time wasting. 16. A hefty amount of certain propaganda pushed on the player. There is a clear moral obligation for the player to make certain choices otherwise the player will be punished in one way or another. 17. Many nonsensical quests like the one with the dragon. Even the puzzles and the "poetry" are nonsense, the quest was clearly rushed. No choice to talk your way out of being enemies either. 18. "Bad" choices are always punished - you lose game content. Instead of having something else happen to you, nothing happens to you instead, and you just never unlock content that is available with a "good" choice.

I remember playing through Act 1 in early access a week before launch Summer 2023. It was fun and intriguing enough but I wasn't super eager to return to it due to other life commitments. When I got around to finishing a full playthrough, though, I thought it was just fine. If you grew up playing CRPG's—especially ones from Bioware, the story feels like a long sequence of highs from those games. It gets exhausting real quick; there's just too much spectacle. It feels hollow, somehow? Almost like I'm reading a YA novel. In-game, I couldn't escape the feeling that I've done all of this before. In my early access playthrough I played as a Tiefling Paladin Oathbreaker. In my full run I changed to Half-Orc, same class but with 'The Dark Urge' origin selected. The difference in race-specific talk options between these two is night and day. The difference between Durge and non-Durge options even more-so. I can't imagine getting through all three Acts as a non-Durge player character. It would end up being more of a slog than it already is. You're supposed to bide your time with the companion quests but they're so unevenly fleshed out I could feel myself growing impatient by the end of Act 2. Each Act has its own main map. Act 1 is massive with a lot of cleverly-designed levels. At times, the sheer amount of interconnectedness feels unending (in a good way). Problems arise when the game restricts you to certain paths as a way of transitioning into the next Act. For example: It seems like I should be able to reach the Gauntlet of Shar from the Grymforge, but no, you to go through nearly all of Act 2 instead. The game never returns to the mystery that made Act 1 so appealing, and once you reach the city in Act 3, you just want it to be over with. I had more fun with Divinity: Original Sin 2.

Just finished a 100-hour playthrough, and I find myself with no one to share my thoughts with, as I have been alone for the past few years. So, consider this a confession — a pouring out of my soul in the hope that it might reach someone who understands what this game made me feel. This is the greatest game I have ever played. I cannot predict whether it will hold that title forever — life is unpredictable — but I can speak for what I have experienced so far. Baldur’s Gate 3 is a masterpiece, a beacon of light in the shadow of everything else I have encountered lately. There is so much I want to say about it. So many things touched the deepest parts of my soul, from its minor mechanics, exploits, and builds to the brilliance of its dice-based gameplay and more. And then there’s the story — one of the most beautiful I have ever experienced, brought to life by an array of vivid characters and unforgettable scenes. When I finished the game, I had only about 30 minutes to watch the final cutscene because the war-torn country I live in suffers from frequent power outages, and I knew I had to see how it all ended. I could not bear to leave the story unfinished. That moment, when everything culminated in Astarion’s simple words, "See you later, darling," at the camp, struck me profoundly. In my life, I have never had friendships like the ones I formed in this game, and I really did not want to say goodbye to them. I know it is just a game. I know I can replay it and explore new outcomes. But this feeling, this powerful ache in my heart, will never be the same. With the deepest gratitude, I want to thank every person who contributed to creating this extraordinary work of art. I fell in love with this game — every single part of it. The quests, dialogues, intrigue, family bonds, betrayals, choices, the seamless flow of the story from beginning to end, the consequences, and yes, even the romance. (Shadowheart, you were incredible, but Karlach… she stole my heart in the end). Every aspect captivated me completely. I do not know how much time I have left on this Earth, nor what lies ahead in my own story. But I know this: this game was a lifeline during one of the darkest, most chaotic times in my life. Amid war, death, and corruption, it reached out to me, pulled me from the abyss and reminded me that there is always something worth fighting for. It taught me that giving up is never an option — no matter what the dice say — and that the best is yet to come. Right now, I feel full. I feel at peace. This game deserves every bit of its 10/10 rating, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone and everyone. With the warmest regards, D

Baldur's Gate 3 is a masterpiece that exceeds expectations on every level. From the moment you step into its richly detailed world, you're entranced by its stunning visuals and masterful storytelling. The character customization is unparalleled, offering depth and nuance that shapes your unique journey. The turn-based combat is both strategic and visually spectacular. Larian Studios has seamlessly blended old-school RPG elements with modern design, creating an immersive experience that pays homage to its legendary predecessors. With a vast, interconnected world and morally complex choices, Baldur's Gate 3 stands as one of the best RPGs, setting a new standard for the genre.

Unpopular opinion time. I didn't like Divinity either, so this being a stinker isn't really that much of a shock. 6 hours in and the combat is still a badly unbalanced railroad. Give the illusion of free choice and exploration, but fail to do the precise order of quests that you MUST and you will crash into impossible odds. Cause and effect are nonsensical; seeing the druid camp explode into an everyone versus everyone riot is beyond illogical. I have zero investment in the party characters, with them all being so fundamentally dislikeable. The idea that 1st level characters have deeply rooted ties to great powers makes no sense either. Combat is decidedly uninteresting as a melee character, which leans the game into being a bard/mage playthrough as not only the default but pretty much mandatory option. Puerile writing, graphics and animation might interest some, but do nothing for the plot or believability of the characters here. Skill checks that if you don't have your character build and party exactly right, at the right time that cannot be adapted to (e.g. the necessary fight by the guardian statues in the Druid Camp). Tiny nods to the legendary BG1, 2 games are welcome; but offer little solace for a game that just isn't terribly much fun to play. I keep trying to come back to this for the sake of playing out the story, but I'd probably be better served by just watching a playthrough on youtube. A shame, given the rave reviews and following this title has. But I just don't like Larian's style. Maybe other developers will get inspired to do something in this space again?

Product received for free [Gift from a friend] I really want to like this game - I want to understand why it's heralded as the second coming of Christ by the gaming community at large. But it's just not clicking for me, even after 60 hours so you can't say I didn't really try to get into it. I'm legitimately frustrated that I'm not finding the joy that so many other people are getting from this; I feel like I'm missing something. First, the negatives: I find combat to be clunky and unintuitive, and generally the same can be said for the UI and interacting with the world. Combat is an absolute slog and easily the worst part of the game. Of course, being shackled to D&D's abysmal magic system also does the game no favors either. Character creation, much like the source material, is a convoluted mess from a gameplay perspective, though props to Larian for adapting so much variation into a single game here. The main narrative felt like it was dragging so much, with side quests offering such basic fantasy tropes as "the evil witch is evil! Oh no!" or "these goblins are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, watch out!" The world-building and combat both felt like Larian expected players to already be familiar with D&D lore and rules, and if you're not well that's just too bad. I felt like I kept returning to the game out of obligation, not curiousity. There's only so many times you can suggest a possible solution to the main mystery only to shout "PSYCH!" to the player before I start getting Lost flashbacks... On the positive side, the game looks beautiful when it's not suffering from distracting pop-in. It mostly runs well and must not be in Unreal Engine because I don't think it ever crashed on me or decided to stutter because the wind blew west for a second. Character models are some of the best I've seen in recent years and the art direction hits a perfect balance between realistic and stylized. It mostly looks real, but it's not afraid to indulge in the weirder or more colorful parts of D&D lore. Dialogue options are also a great time to play with, especially when trying to use your character's specialties and abilities. The party characters are very memorable and likeable, even the intentionally unlikeable ones. And generally the music is good, even if I may have some light PTSD from hearing that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ combat music. I don't know. I feel like I did playing The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword HD - there's clearly something of quality here, but there's an ungracefulness in its overall presentation that's hurting my enjoyment. Like that game, I may put this on a list of games to potentially revisit in the distant future to try again and see if they click with an older, changed version of myself. But for now...this feels like a criminally overrated experience.

This game has defined the gold standard for RPGs in my opinion, sitting at the same table as classic RPGs like Mass Effect and Fallout New Vegas and even surpassing them. I’ve put about 146 hours into Baldur’s Gate 3, and it was my first real dice-based RPG. It ended up being one of the most rewarding games I’ve played in years. The amount of choice and reactivity is impressive. Your decisions actually matter, both in dialogue and in combat, and there are countless ways to approach the same situation depending on your party, skills, and creativity. It makes every playthrough feel personal instead of scripted. The story, characters, and world are all extremely well done, and the turn-based combat has enough depth to stay interesting even deep into the game. If you enjoy story-driven RPGs with meaningful choices and tactical combat, this is an easy recommendation.

After 23+ years of playing games, I think I finally have an answer to what my favorite game of all time is: - Unbelievable voice acting and facial animations during dialogue. The writing is incredible. The characters are so likeable, from main questline characters to a random cow on the side of the road. I have the attention span ****, but not 1 conversation in this game has lost my attention for more than 5 seconds. - Your choices matter, and not in the Tod Howard sort of way. The game totally changes depending on your choices of which there are countless. It makes you want to play through the entire game multiple times just to experience how different each playthrough is. - Tactical, turn-based combat with so many different ways to approach any given encounter. The difficulty can vary drastically depending on your plan going into a fight, and there is a massive amount of freedom in how you choose to exploit an enemies weaknesses if you are willing to look for them. - The character creation and class system is deep, and only becomes deeper as you level up and unlock more skills and traits for your characters. Each class can showcase it's own utility in all things including combat, world traversal and dialogue. Every character in your party will have their uses depending on the situation. - The story is phenomenal from start to finish. It initially makes you feel somewhat insignificant as an entity in a massive world with so much going on around you, yet also makes your decisions for you and your party feel important and impactful to the world you inhabit. There are twists you don't expect, as well as tough decisions to make that can drastically change your playthrough. And the game is paced beautifully as it slowly builds and builds in tension and intrigue. Overall this game is probably the most shockingly good game I've ever played. I haven't tried any of the previous instalments in the series, and I had hardly heard of it up until it released this month. But it has ended up, in my mind, being a must-win for game of the Year, even in a year with so many great games being released. This is a special piece of media made by people that clearly truly care about what they have made and they deserve all the success they are having for it.

Baldur’s Gate 3: A Masterpiece That Truly Deserved Game of the Year Let me just say this upfront: Baldur’s Gate 3 isn’t just a game—it’s an experience. From the moment you start your journey, you realize you’re stepping into something special, something crafted with an insane level of care and detail. It’s the kind of game that grabs you and doesn’t let go, and it 100% deserved Game of the Year. First off, the freedom this game gives you is unparalleled. You can approach almost any situation in so many ways—talk your way out, fight your way through, or use the environment to outsmart your enemies. The sheer amount of choice is mind-blowing. Want to play as a sneaky rogue who talks circles around everyone? Go for it. Maybe you’d rather be a wild magic sorcerer who occasionally sets themselves on fire by accident—it’s all possible. And the choices aren’t just limited to combat. Your dialogue, actions, and even the people you travel with all shape the story in meaningful ways. The story itself is phenomenal. It’s deep, emotional, and filled with twists that keep you hooked. Every character you meet feels like they have their own life and motivations. Your party members, especially, are just fantastic. From the snarky Astarion to the noble Shadowheart, everyone has layers to uncover. And the way your relationships evolve with them based on your decisions? Chef’s kiss. You’re not just playing through a pre-written story—you’re crafting your own epic. Now let’s talk about the gameplay. The combat is turn-based, which I’ll admit I was unsure about at first. But wow, it’s so much fun. Every battle feels like a puzzle to solve, and when you land a big combo or pull off a clever move using the environment, it’s insanely satisfying. Even outside of combat, the game encourages creativity. Spells and abilities aren’t just for fighting—you can use them to solve puzzles, bypass obstacles, or even just mess around. It makes you feel like you’re truly inhabiting a living, breathing world. Another reason Baldur’s Gate 3 is so much fun is the co-op. Playing this with friends is a blast. You’ll find yourselves laughing over ridiculous decisions, debating over moral choices, or just reveling in the chaos someone’s wild plan inevitably creates. It’s the kind of game that creates stories you’ll be talking about for years. The visuals and voice acting deserve a shoutout too. The environments are gorgeous, with so much attention to detail that every location feels unique and immersive. And the voice acting? Top-notch. The performances bring every character to life and make the emotional moments hit even harder. Finally, it’s worth mentioning just how polished this game is. It’s a rarity these days to play a game that feels so complete at launch. Baldur’s Gate 3 set a new standard for what RPGs should be. In the end, Baldur’s Gate 3 isn’t just fun—it’s an achievement. It’s the kind of game that reminds you why you love gaming in the first place. Whether you’re here for the story, the gameplay, or just to see how wild your decisions can get, it delivers on every front. This is what Game of the Year looks like.

I’ve always loved RPGs but I never thought a CRPG grounded in tabletop DNA would land this hard for me. Baldur’s Gate 3 didn’t just meet my expectations for character-driven storytelling and decision-making, it redefined them. Compared to narrative titans like Mass Effect, KOTOR, Fallout, or Elder Scrolls, this game doesn’t just stand beside them, it looks them in the eye. Your choices in BG3 feel deeply personal, not just in dialogue but in action, consequence, and the relationships that grow (or shatter) because of them. You explore at your own pace, and that freedom is powerful but also dangerous. The game won’t stop you from making a reckless decision, and it certainly won’t stop a dragon-riding Githyanki from reminding you why that was a mistake. There’s a quiet respect in how the game trusts you to find your own way, even when it leads to disaster. There were moments I laughed out loud, sat back in awe, or felt genuine tension about a decision. And all of it was driven by my own choices, not scripted “gotchas,” but the natural result of living in a world that responds (although not powerful enough to overcome my save scumming). If you’re a fan of RPGs and haven’t tried this yet, you owe it to yourself. And if you’re unsure about the CRPG format? I was too. This game changed that.

💌 Score: 10/10 👍🏻 Pros ✔️ Consequential choices that reshape the world and story ✔️ Deep, evolving companion relationships ✔️ Gorgeous, detailed visuals and dynamic lighting ✔️ Tactically rich turn-based combat ✔️ Outstanding voice work and epic soundtrack 👎🏻 Cons ❌ A few companions (Wyll, Halsin) could use more dedicated content ❌ Occasional performance dips in densely populated areas ❌ Long load times between certain zones 🌦️ Introduction Baldur’s Gate 3 rightly earned its GOTY 2023 crown. Every decision—big or small—ripples through the world, making each playthrough uniquely personal. The real magic, however, lies in its cast of companions—each character grows richer the more time you spend with them. The game’s Unreal Engine 4-powered graphics bring Faerûn to life with stunning detail. From the flicker of torchlight in shadowy dungeons to the lush canopies of the Emerald Grove, environments feel both vibrant and immersive. Character models and spell effects pop with cinematic flair, making every cutscene and encounter a visual treat. Larian Studios’ turn-based adaptation of D&D 5th Edition shines here. Combat is tactical and satisfying, with terrain, cover, and status effects all playing critical roles. Outside of battle, the freedom to explore, experiment with spells, and combine environmental elements (like igniting oil slicks) makes every approach uniquely yours. The interface can be dense at first, but it rewards patient players with limitless creative possibilities. At its heart, Baldur’s Gate 3 is driven by the weight of choices and the bonds you form. Decisions can steer the story toward salvation or disaster, with your companions’ arcs evolving in tandem—whether it’s Shadowheart’s journey toward redemption, Karlach’s fierce but loyal spirit, Gale’s precarious charm, or Astarion’s biting wit. Even characters like Minthara and the returning Jaheira leave a strong impression when they enter your story. Minsc, another beloved figure from the original games, adds a nostalgic yet heartfelt energy to the party with his unwavering heroism and hilarious quips. Though I initially found Lae’zel difficult to connect with, her development made me grow to respect her. Wyll and Halsin have standout moments too, though I wish their stories were explored in more depth. The soundtrack swells with epic orchestral themes that underscore major story beats, while subtler motifs highlight quieter moments of reflection. Voice acting across the board is superb—each companion’s tone matches their personality perfectly, from Minsc’s boisterous war cries to Gale’s earnest reflections on his arcane affliction. Baldur’s Gate 3 masterfully blends player choice, memorable characters, and high-stakes drama into an RPG triumph. Whether you’re negotiating peace between factions or grappling with the fate of your own soul, the game delivers an experience you’ll revisit time and again.

10/10 – A Masterclass in Storytelling, Freedom, and Chaos Baldur’s Gate 3 isn’t just a video game — it’s an experience that completely redefines what role-playing means. From the very first dice roll, it feels like stepping into a living, breathing Dungeons & Dragons campaign with the best dungeon master imaginable. Every character, choice, and consequence feels handcrafted with care, depth, and humor. You start as a nobody infected with a mind flayer parasite, and before you know it, you’re leading a ragtag band of misfits through one of the most immersive worlds ever built. The writing is sharp and layered — funny when it wants to be, dark when it needs to be, and emotional when you least expect it. Every companion has a backstory that feels worth exploring, and the relationships you build (or ruin) genuinely matter. The freedom of choice is mind-blowing. You can fight your way through every obstacle, sweet-talk your enemies into helping you, or just… throw a pair of boots at someone and see what happens. You can romance half your party (and probably regret it later), betray your allies, or save the world through sheer luck and questionable decisions. Almost everything you think of trying — the game lets you do. Combat is deep but approachable. Turn-based battles feel tactical and satisfying, and the environment plays a huge role — whether you’re pushing people off ledges, lighting grease on fire, or turning into a gas cloud to sneak past danger. It rewards creativity and punishes recklessness in the most entertaining ways possible. And then there’s the presentation — breathtaking visuals, incredible voice acting, and a musical score that perfectly captures every moment. The game feels alive. NPCs react to your actions, the world changes based on your choices, and even minor side quests can turn into full-blown adventures. It’s not just about beating the game — it’s about living through it. You’ll laugh, you’ll rage, you’ll reload saves you swore you wouldn’t, and when the credits finally roll, you’ll sit there in silence wondering what would have happened if you’d made just one different choice. After hundreds of hours, I can confidently say this: Baldur’s Gate 3 isn’t just one of the best RPGs ever made — it’s one of the best games ever made, period. Verdict: A critical hit in every category. Don’t just play it — live it.

There's SOOOO much good content, Rp and seemingly random things going on that it's impossible to fight the urge to look up other people's play-through's, ask the internet if you're making a good choice or choosing the right items or companions for an interaction that you can't really blame yourself if you spend 5hrs in game (out of game) looking at an IGN article about if the helmet is better than the shield or if this NPC can be saved. There's a reason most people have over 100 hrs in this game and I can assure you it is both enriching and concerning. The only thing that my family and I didn't like was the POV, because we're used to being able to look up at the sky when ever we want, but that's a personal preference and not an issue with the game. I just wanted to express empathy for anyone who's not used to top down 3rd person (people who don't regularly play (LOL and Dota) type games ) getting into this one with a misconception that the majority of the game outside of combat will be different. This obvious assumption is made by the fact most places only show cut-scenes, low angle 3rd person and FPOV's over all when sharing content. The only image that is largely accurate on the steam page for example (without forcing the camera) is the cursed forge image where the characters look like they're far away. The good news is you can get used to the angle after 9hrs of play time. Would recommend, don't feel shy about making the settings what you want/need them to be so that you can enjoy this awesome story telling experience.

Score: ★★★★★ (5/5) — Still finding new reasons to love it after 165 hours. But even then, I can’t deny the incredible attention to detail, character depth, and the sheer number of choices that can shift your story in surprising ways. That “your choice matters” gameplay has always been one of my favorite mechanics, and BG3 does it better than almost any RPG I’ve played. Overall, Baldur’s Gate 3 is a masterpiece that continues to grow with every update. If you enjoy immersive storytelling, role-playing freedom, and a developer that truly listens to its community, you’ll find yourself right at home here, just like I did.

Okay, wow, where to start? After a year I finally managed to pick it back up and finish the last of Act 3. When it had first came out I had been completely obsessed. I did every mission I could find, searched every crate, played around by trying different choices (admittedly a bit of savescumming on my behalf). And I remember it being so much fun. The characters (and the amazing voice acting), the world building, the choices. Any other review can probably tell you just how this game excells in everything. The only miniscule "complaint" I could possibly have is the fact Act 3 is so huge, and not super structured, so I had to do a bit on research on the correct order of doing things to not miss anything. I think since it was such an overwhelming amount of content, past me just couldn't keep up with it at the time because of exams. I'm kind of a perfectionist, so picking it back up where I could barely remember what I last did felt a bit difficult. But god was it worth it. The story ended beautifully (I went for a good playthrough), and the satisfaction it gave me to finally complete my first playthrough was inmense. The nostalgia (from when I last played and enjoyed this game) and all the fun I had had was one I wish to repeat. An emotional breath of fresh air that even someone who knows nothing about DnD can learn to love just as much. So glad it got game of the year award in 2024, definetely deserved. I recommend it 100%, and will likely in the future begin another playthrough as dark urge instead (there's way too much replayability not to!). Definitely one of my favourite games.

I did not understand the fighting mechanics and I was close to giving up. As you can see from this review, I did not.. I decided to play a little bit more, and 2 hours turned into 5 hours, and 5 hours turned into 50 hours, and 50 hours to 100 hours…. This is the best story I have ever experienced in a game. All the choices, mistakes and accomplishments matters and I am able to craft my own story. How is it even possible to make a game where there is a story line for ever possible outcome? I played it for so long and did so many quests, but I still feel like I just scratched the surface of the game, and I am ready to play it again and do things differently. I usually never want to play the story from a single-player game more than once, but I feel like I can play this 5 more times and have completely different experiences and outcomes. I still don’t understand half of it, and the game is hard, but that is just fine. There is so much to learn, so many more stories to experience. I finally understand why so many people like these type of games. 10/10! Btw, remember to backup save all the time! I learned that the hard way…

Only had the game for a couple of weeks and over 100hrs in. When my bro suggested it, I was like “meh..role-play.. not my thing”. But then I thought, “Well, I used to play Tunnels and Trolls and D&D when it first came out, so I wonder what it’s like on ps5” So, so glad I did. The mix of turn based and group movement make the game move along smoothly. I find the coma at fun and challenging. I normally steer away from magic as I’m a hack’n’slash kinda guy, but here it’s necessary and enjoyable to use. However,, what makes this game stand out for me are the depth of the character choices and the way that decisions really do have significant repercussions in the game going forward. Character and group decisions mean you have to approach combat scenarios based on your party skills, allowing for multiple playthroughs (however, I’m still in Act 2 after 110hrs). But the main thing is the writing and scenario design. Some encounters are beautifully designed with stunning graphics; some are really challenging; and some are really funny. The behind-the-scenes dice rolling is seamless meaning some traps reallydo take you by surprise. The characters have real depth; so that some that I didn’t warm to at the start are now my favourites (take care though, my bro was a bit careless in his early interactions and two of his party upped sticks and left for good!). I would definitely say this is the most pleasantly surprised I have ever been about a game..ever (well, that I remember.. Silent Hill 1 was a long time ago!). Add to that the continued support and updates from the devs and this, for me, is the one absolutely must have game on next-gen. It has something for everyone. I haven’t tried multiplayer yet, as I like to do first play through alone; so still got that to look forward to. A masterpiece imo; and a bargain at the price.

[End of Edit] First things first: I (over)paid the full price for this game, I've finished the game and understand mechanics. I wish I was on recieving end of money that went into pockets of content creators who shilled for this bad game. This game is bad on one hand and boring on the other. The single thing that it more or less does well is exploration, everything else is bad and boring. OST is ruinning immersion. The fighting song is like "BOOOBOBOBABIIII BIBIBIOOO" - like, are we fighting, or trying to help a toddler to utter their first words? BUGS everywhere - interestingly, the longer I play, the more of them appear and more ridiculous they are. I started a new run and triggers went off badly, so I couldn't skip a cutscene and each scene was played 3 times in a row (reloading game didn't fix this). After finishing the game on balanced I've went for tactician and suddenly it turned out that having 75+% hit chance makes me land 1 in 8 hits, getting critical fails 2-3 times in a row every second turn, while my enemies who have 25% hit chance were hitting me 9 out of 12 times, getting at least one crit every turn. First I thought it's RNG cheating coz of difficulty, but when I verified files for the game it fixed itself and I no longer get utter nonsense from RNG - which shouldn't happen. Somehow this game destroys itself when you play it. Fights are incredibly boring. Creators of the game don't respect your time at all - you have turnbased fights (what is it? 1994? where's active pause?) which can't be sped up and take ages (AI sometimes hangs and you have to reload the fight) and fights often have meaningless mobs that just artificially make them longer. Speaking of making things artificially longer, you have to throw a k20 dice for almost everything and A LOT of these are direct rolls, where UI animates the roll - what is this nonsense? there's literally no other reason, than to fake that the game has much more content than it really does. Another thing is the team-UI, which is basically nonexistant. How is it possible, that even indie games do it properly, but this ♥♥♥♥ game has NO party features? This makes traps and lockpicking even more time consuming, tedious and boring than it naturally is, because if you don't play as a rogue, you have to select your rouge manually and order him to lockpick or disarm after rightclicking a box or trap - the UI isn't smart enough to send the best hero for the task nor to know you want to lockpick a locked chest or disarm a trap - ridiculous! Legendary items are +3 -BORING AND PATHETIC! Character leveling is designed to give you depression : there's basically no choices to make except for picking specialty at level 3. Levleups do almost nothing, but for whatever reason lvl5 more than doubles your hero's power, with most classes having some cherry on the top imba mechanic on lvl6 which is just awful design. Unless you play a spellcaster at which point "awful" gets into new quality. Woah, look 4 goblins, lets kill them! Oh, oops, now we have to long rest, because casters no longer have spells :(. BOOOOOORRRRIIINNNNGGGGG!!!! Nothing makes sense in this game, people who made these mechanics never touched grass. You can jump up to a place, but jumping down makes you take damage, while jumping down is easier than jumping up to something. wtf? and another example: woah, I have 22 strength? Time to pick up this dude and throw him at his friends - well, yes, but the range is tiny - oh, ok, I guess you need big big strenght then. Oh look a dragon! how strong is it? 26 strenght. And no, these don't increase exponentially. And no, odd values don't do anything. There's basically no difference between 20 and 21 strenght. 26 strength lets a dragon carry it's gigantic body around in a swift fashion, but 22 won't let you toss an enemy from one side of the screen to another. there are 4 stairs between you and your target? well now you can't shoot an arrow through these door until you walk these 4 stairs. You're at a highground? well tough ♥♥♥♥, because some highground prevent you from shooting down. You can miss a statue that can't move (and not through critical miss). You sneaked up on that enemy and want to do a stealth kill? shame, coz you've MISSED this mob that wasn't moving nor defending itself :D Almost all feats are useless, while other few are just straight imbalanced (like tavern brawler). Almost all items are trash. (yeah, the game is boring). There's no facilities for looting - if there's 20 enemies dead, you need to go to each of them separately and loot bodies 20 times. All items are clickable, which means - you've guessed it - microing looting of ♥♥♥♥ from crates, which should be automated becuase it's 2025. A d20 roll can separate you from content FOREVER. A buggy trigger can separate you from content FOREVER or even KILL YOUR HONOUR RUN! Now that's great isn't it? Monk is imbalanced. Giant berserker is imbalanced. Arcane archer is imbalanced - and there are actually even more imba things in the game. You basically have the same level for the entire team, but not exactly. If your main hero gets a level earlier, just tell your companion to wait in camp and then rejoin - they get the levelup. You get the same amount of exp no matter how many companions you have, so what's the point of them having separate exp bars? This means if you're solo, you don't get more exp, which is SOOO BOOOOOORING! lvl12 is max and you will never get any hero development above that. I had lvl12 somewhere at the beginning of act 3 and I know that minmaxing you can get even to lvl 11 before act2. Surprise mechanics are bugged and nonsense since you can force the entire enemy pack to be surprised by a single unit from your pack, even if they joined the fight unsurprised. I don't remember a game disappointing me this much and a lot of it is the absurd price for it and the all the lies about what a great game this is. It is not. It's a SCAM! Somehow Tyranny could make it's mechanics to be modern and exciting ( even the spellcasting ). I thought that Colony Ship is the most terrible RPG I've played with most annoying mechanics, but I was wrong. If you treat Colony ship as a tactics challenge for fighting, then it's actually fun, becuase you can be creative with how you build your character when it levels up and moreover it's FUN that you can get a single character run and leverage that bit of extra exp. Again, I don't even get scammed this hard by politicians from my corrupt government. It doesn't even get close to the SCAM this game is.

I was trying to come up with a critique of BG3 but all I could think was in how I could kick a squirrel down the forest. Despite what most people say, I wouldn't recommend the game to just ANYBODY. I wouldn't call it a masterpiece. The story in its moment to moment can be very corny, you won't completely shake off the feeling that you a playing in a homebrew D&D campaign which can undermine its more serious moments. The party limit of 4 instead of the standar 6 feels pretty restrictive. Just 12 levels seems pretty low, which I didn't mind since I figured out that Larian would follow the BG tradition of making an expansion that would fill the missing levels until you learn that the studio is not interested in pursuing further content outside of what a patch can provide. What really shines is the moment to moment gameplay and the sheer comedy effect that just get multiplied when you play with friends. And if you are a newcomer, I think that all the negatives you can pull from the game won't matter as much and some will even help you out get into RPGs with things like having the more manageable party of 4, more comprehensible level cap of 12 and the fact the navegation feels more like an exploration game rather than a top-down RPG. Let me put you this way: If you want a RPG with a good story that takes itself serious and makes you ponder about it narrative and characters, play Planescape Torment of the Pillar's of Eternity games. If you want sheer content with dozens of classes, with many options to build your party and be able to reach your power fantasy, play the Pathfinder Games or BG1 & 2. If you want to have a fun with your friends or you want to play a good-looking rpg with a lot of production value and a bunch of tools to let you break havoc in the forgotten realms, get BG3. You won't regret it.

Giving this a 5 because I’m only able to play half of the game due to Larian updating the game with a patch that completely broke Act 3. The lag is insane taking 30sec to a minute for NPC and party members to respond (this is offline, mind you), then you move your character a bit and it happens again, and again, and again. Crossing the lower city is a half hour exercise in pure frustration. Some encounters actually cause the game to crash altogether, and that’s not a one-off. I’ve had the same encounter crash the game on my PS5 4 times. I tried deleting and reinstalling the game - no change. The first half of the game was great fun and I’ve played it through twice, but then running into game-breaking performance issues upon arriving in Baldur’s Gate has ruined my initial impression of the game. To add insult to injury, more than 2 weeks after that game-breaking patch Larian has yet to comment on it in the media, their own forums, or anywhere else despite a large player outcry. So now I’ve spent money on a game the developer’s actions have prevented me from completing and that same developer has nothing to say. I’ll think twice before buying any title from Larian in the future.

I'm using more skills and spells now, and having a lot of fun. I just find the overall fighting system inferior to what DoS2 had. I miss using the many elements and their combinations. In DoS2 you could throw everything you had at the enemy and still have a good challenge. Here if you throw everything, it's too easy. I went into this game with some hesitation. I’d never played a turn-based D&D game before, and coming from games like Skyrim, I thought immersion meant real-time combat and full freedom of movement. BG3 completely changed how I see that. I’ve spent over ten hours barely leaving the starting area—not because the game is slow, but because there’s so much happening everywhere. Every conversation feels worth having, every place feels like it has a story, and the game actually trusts you to figure things out instead of holding your hand. Curiosity constantly pays off in ways I didn’t expect. What really surprised me is how heavy the choices feel. For the first time in an RPG, the main threat doesn’t feel like something you can just ignore while doing side quests. It’s always in the back of your mind, and it made me genuinely anxious about what I should do next. I even felt tempted to look things up, before realising that the uncertainty is part of the experience. This isn’t a game where the world bends around you. Your actions matter, your approach matters, and things don’t always work out the way you expect. Baldur’s Gate 3 doesn’t just let you play a role—it makes you live with it. Easy 10/10. One of the most immersive RPGs I’ve ever played - and I've barely started Act I.

An amazing game and a labor of love that is rare to find in today's AAA gaming environment. Baldur's Gate 3 is a great adaption of the D&D 5th edition rules and Forgotten Realms lore built into a turn based RPG that you can play alone or with friends. It also feels like a great improvement over Larian Studios previous stellar game Divinity Original Sin 2. While those who are expecting gameplay other than turn-based combat or the rules/mechanics to be more akin to Baldur's Gate 1 and 2 may be disappointed, this remains a faithful Baldur's Gate experience full of environments to explore and quests to complete in a multitude of ways. Larian has out done themselves with updating and supporting the game to allow players to creatively approach the game. The cherry on the top is the music and voice acting that carry the game to a higher level of immersion. The only minor complaint I have had is sometimes trying to approach a fight with multiple characters separated from each other and having no real way to pause the fight to let them all jump in with a surprise attack. If the first one to attack rolls low and the enemies do not get the surprised status, they'll begin to attack the one character and possibly spot your other party members, forcing them to roll initiative and enter combat.
Variety of gameplay is limited to your imagination - be as good or evil as you like.

I ummed arred as to whether or not to give this a positive or negative review. If there was a neutral option I would pick that. This game left me feeling odd, I liken it a weird after taste after eating something that initially tasted good.

I've been playing video games for 30 years. I was really starting to lose hope that any developers or studios would ever push the envelope again. Take risks and challenge themselves. Listen to the players and release a video game worthy of our time and money. I can't really nail down ALL the reasons why Baldur's Gate 3 has enslaved me now going on 100 hours. I think it's the entire presentation. They get so many things right. And then they go out of their way to show you more. It just never stops. There's never a lull in the story or in the action. Never a period of just grinding out XP to level up by farming one location over and over again. They didn't just put a new coat of paint on the genre. This is the genre. In fact, I don't know if anyone has ever been making CRPGs correctly so you might be like me and have never experienced something like this. I haven't been this excited for the future of gaming in over a decade. I can't wait to see how other studios respond. The inter-connectivity between everything going on in this game borders on unsettling. Like you're being tricked or something. You get these moments where you're like, "Hey, what . . wait a second??" Like this one where I found a stray dog on the road guarding his master's dead body. My Druid could speak with animals and is very persuasive so we were able to talk the dog into coming back to our camp for food and shelter. He ended up staying and is just our dog now. But he found this red ball one random time when I was at camp and he had it in his mouth and I took it, then I used the throw command and the dog chased it. Pretty neat. Kudos. But then about 60 in-game hours later this happened. I'm on a main-line quest and I decide to go rogue. I break into this balcony and lock-pick the door from the outside. My party all crowd into the room and there's this un-dead dog barking and going crazy. The game cuts away to a list of prompts to see how I want to proceed.. And one of them reads "Maybe you still have that red ball that Twitch was playing with." AND I DID!! I had it with me throughout the whole game. I had the dog sniff it and then I rolled against my Animal Handling to try and calm him down all the way. Which failed after 6 attempted rolls and 3 save games. So I did have to murder that un-dead dog. But I couldn't believe that little red ball made such an unexpected appearance way later in the game. Its that connectivity between everything. Even things that don't relate or won't ever be in the same room together. That random chance, or forgetting something small, seeing coincidences and wondering if they mean something. That **** really makes this world feel like an actual place. Random connections and coincidences happen if life all the time. Never thought I'd see it in a game that felt this authentic. One last thing while I'm here. I was debating this so I rolled for it. Here we go. I've never done this before in any review. There are some games that I cherish dearly. I don't know if I've ever said this about any game. Maybe in a drunk conversation. SONIC FRONTIERS IS THE GREATEST F**KING GAME EVER!! FIGHT ME!!! But I've never truly believed that I had arrived at that conclusion with any game. And I believed I would live the rest of my life without ever making such a bold and ridiculous claim. However, Larien Studios has shown us otherwise. The impossible has been achieved. Baldur's Gate 3, in-my-opinion, is the greatest game ever made. That's a very opinionated and biased statement that is definitely worth debating so I'll leave that at that and finish with what I do know to be absolutely true. Baldur's Gate 3 is my favorite game of all time. Ever. This has been a stunning year in gaming. Might end up being the best year in gaming . . . ever. So Baldur's Gate 3 didn't have a blank slate of bored gamers with nothing great to play. Because there has been multiple instances of greatness this year. I think It's fitting that in a year filled with so many great titles, one of them would not only stand high above the rest, but make a play for all-time greatness. Now then, you people have wasted enough of my precious BG3 time. I really hope everyone enjoys this amazing and so very special game. If you don't, don't blame my review. Blame your parents.

Baldur's Gate 3 Guardian cutscene killed my mid-range computer. Hence - an obviously negative review. I will change it to a positive review if it doesn't kill my new one. Larian, it's been a couple of years now of players reporting hard crashes on all sorts of machines and systems. Does someone have to sue you before you guys actually look into it? I had a great time for 230 hours but now I'm down 2,500 USD and I am scared to play the game again after reading reports of destroyed PC's ranging from 10 year old work laptops to 2 month old 4090 baby beasts. I guess it's back to playing new games about 10 years after they come out for me, but PLEASE Larian. Do something about this. The game is so enjoyable, so it's just a travesty that you would let something like this go for so many years now. Whenever I get the new PC I will try to recover my files and crash reports from my old one and I will obviously send in a ticket to figure out what happened, but for now I feel like I had to voice this concern since not everyone has the money to risk the most important hardware in their home (as it is for many gamers) just because the issue is hard for you to pinpoint. I genuinely hope this issue eventually gets resolved and I can go back to wholeheartedly enjoying the game like I did before all this happened.
